answer.para: Australia does have laws, which you are aware of, which prohibit the monopolisation and concentration of market power. Section 50 of the Trade Practices Act generally prohibits mergers or acquisitions which have the effect or the likely effect of lessening competition in a substantial market for goods and services. Of course, parties can also apply for an exemption from section 50 which will be given if they can demonstrate substantial public benefits from the merger or acquisition taking place.
Under section 46 of the Trade Practices Act, that prohibits a business that has substantial market power—
I think that is the point you are making—from taking advantage:
. . . of that power for the purpose of:
(a) eliminating or substantially damaging a competitor . . .
That may have been the underlying theme that ran through your question. It goes on:
. . . or
(b) preventing the entry of a person in that or any other market; or
(c) deterring or preventing a person from engaging in competitive conduct in that or any other market.
As I said, where you feel you do have some evidence of anti-competitive behaviour, it is up to you—if you wish to—to bring it to the Productivity Commission.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is an independent statutory authority which is responsible for ensuring compliance with the competitive conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act. It is easy to stand up and impute motives to people but, if you feel that you have the evidence, the doors are open to you to make a complaint.

The final point I would make is that the Productivity Commission—which, if I remember rightly, I do not think you are the greatest fan of, Senator Margetts—will be undertaking a public inquiry into the impact of competition reforms on rural and regional Australia. Again, if you have concerns, you may wish to make a submission to the Productivity Commission. I am sure that they will be pleased to hear from you.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister says that I can contact the ACCC. We have. The ACCC say they have no power to deal with anti-competitive outcomes, and that is what I am talking about. Given that the Western Australian Council of Retail Associations has estimated that 1,800 full-time jobs were lost for every one per cent of growth in the big chain stores and the last ABS retail industry Australia survey of 1991-92 outlined that every one full-time job in large discount stores equates to 2.25 jobs in smaller shops, and that one part-time job in large discount stores equals 1.5 part-time jobs in smaller shops, does the government recognise that this concentration in market power of large retailers is having a negative impact on employment in Australia? Does the government think this negative employment impact is a good enough reason in itself for them to investigate this incredible concentration of market power?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —One of the points that I would make in response to the question is that it is generally agreed that Australia overall has to become more competitive. Australia has to have an economy which can effectively compete in the world economy.
—This is oligopoly.
—Why don't you free up newsagents?

—It is very easy to make a general complaint, but you have to put down the specifics. You have to recognise that, where you believe there are detrimental outcomes as a result, you can take your concerns to the ACCC. I have to tell you, Senator, that the door is open to you in relation to an inquiry which is being done by the Productivity Commission. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Can the minister confirm that, since the transfer of jurisdiction from the former Industrial Relations Court in early 1997, the court is still staffed by 30 persons and that some of these staff will remain under contract until December 1999? Is the minister aware that the salaries of the judicial registrars with nothing to do was almost $1.4 million in 1997-98 and that the total cost for staff and accommodation for this non-existent court was $6.76 million last financial year? How can the government possibly defend this disgraceful waste of money and court resources—potentially up to $15 million—between the closure of the court and the expiry of all staff contracts?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Murphy for the question. You ask about the cost of making what this government believes are appropriate changes, and you make the assertion that any cost involved in making those changes, vis-a-vis the industrial court, is not worth bearing. I do not impute any bad faith to you; I simply say that I do not take the figures you assert at face value. I will go away and ask someone in the Attorney's office to verify those figures. If there is anything in particular that merits a further response, I will come back to you.

answer.para: I just make the point—it is a pretty obvious one to everybody else, I would have thought—that there is often a cost to making a change. People like you over there want to focus on that cost without focusing on the benefit. That is the mistake you make all the time. You are always complaining about what you see as the negatives and never looking at all the good things that follow from them.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We might accept that there might be a cost, but the general idea would be to try to minimise those costs. Given that you will investigate the matter, can you also confirm that these staff, particularly the judicial registrars, have had negligible work since the transfer of the court's jurisdiction and that this situation continues despite various promises of appropriate work coming from the Federal Court? Minister, why were these legal resources not put into use in the Federal Court or the Industrial Relations Commission, instead of just wasting some $7 million each year until the end of the century?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —Once again, I do not take the figures you put forward as being ones that one should necessarily believe. I do not take them at face value. I will get them checked. I do not assume that these people have not had appropriate work to do, but I will refer your question to the Attorney. If he wants to say anything to you about it, he will.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Is the minister aware of a misleading scare campaign currently under way in regional communities about the government's commitment to post offices in rural and regional Australia? Is the government committed to full public ownership of Australia Post and maintaining the present standard letter service at a uniform price for all Australians?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We said a number of things about Australia Post before the last election and paramount amongst them was the proposition—
—You also had a lot to say about the ABC. Do you remember that?

—And anything I did say had nothing to do with any pre-election commitments, and you well know it. What we did say about Australia Post is that we would never privatise it; in other words, it would remain 100 per cent government owned. We also said that we would maintain the standard letter service; in other words, that all Australians would be guaranteed a standard letter service at a uniform price wherever they happened to live.

answer.para: Now those were cast iron, rock solid guarantees; and we have delivered in full. Not only that, but, in response to a recent report from the National Competition Council, we also made it very clear that our response would not involve the closure of any post offices or mail centres. The Prime Minister has said that and I have said that ad nauseam. I have also ruled out the NCC's principal recommendation which was that the business mail market be fully deregulated, and I have made it very clear that Australia Post's CSO will continue to be fully funded by way of an internal cross-subsidy.

None of that has stopped the most shameless and disgracefully dishonest scare campaign in living memory. One very good example of that is this sort of rubbish that goes out from the CEPU, either taxpayer funded or union funded—but it doesn't really matter. The really lazy ones, like Senator Schacht, just have an overprint saying, `Printed and authorised and with the compliments of.' And what does it start with? It says, `The Howard government's National Competition Council.' Well, who set it up? This was the Keating-Beazley National Competition Council, right? It is an arms-length independent outfit. It is not ours. If it is ours, it sure is yours.

It goes on with things like, `It is estimated that up to 15,000 of the approximately 40,000 employees will lose their jobs.' Estimated by whom? Of course, it is estimated by no-one except the union, who are out there trying to scare the pants off ordinary people in rural areas. You look at the numbers on it—I don't expect you to have read this, all you did was put a stamp on it, but if you do read it one time what you will see is claims that more than half the post offices in Australia will close as a result of this. The only possible way you could get to a figure of that dimension is to assume that somehow Australia Post would, overnight, lose every last cent of the revenue it earns from its currently reserved service.

It is a preposterous allegation, because the facts are that in the last five full years before you got thrown out, you managed to close nearly 300 post offices. That was your performance figure. That is the bottom line for you. In the two full years since we have been in government, we have actually opened up more than 150. Look at the trend line. It is a preposterous and disgraceful campaign that is being run. The worst part about it is that if we did have truth in advertising, you would get five years for this—for misleading and deceptive conduct—because it is quite clear that no-one in their right mind would believe such nonsense.

You continue to think that you can sit back on your oars, as you have done for the last two and a half years. Your idea of earning a living is to wander in here for an hour each day and slag off at the government; then, when parliament is not sitting, you wander around your electorate trying to whip up monumental scare campaigns; and you put your hand out to be paid as though you have done a full day's work.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, would you like to elaborate further on the impact of Labor policy on the Australia Post services under the previous government's regime?
—Senator Heffernan, that question is out of order.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, can you confirm that the government's savings rebate which has been promoted as an incentive to save is the same rebate that Treasury officials confirmed in Senate estimates would not in fact increase national savings? Is this the same savings rebate that high wealth individuals can get, even if they wind back their total savings over the course of a year? Is this also the same savings rebate which will give a bonus of $450 for taxpayers getting income from $60,000 or so of investments while wage and salary earners, who do not usually pay personal superannuation contributions, will receive on average only $20 per year?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Isn't this typical of the Labor Party? Here we have a major government initiative to encourage savings and all you can do, in the usual Labor Party style, is stand up and knock it. Senator, let me make a couple of points which will assist you.

answer.para: We were able to deliver an incentive for savings. Your party was not able to deliver. You remember the 1993 election when you went to the people promising l-a-w law tax cuts? You remember that? What happened? Failed to deliver. Then the Labor Party said, `We can't actually deliver our l-a-w law cuts, so what we will do is throw this whole issue off to the never-never and develop what we will call the co-contribution scheme,' which cut in years later. The truth of the matter is you could never deliver that, you could not afford that. So the first point is that we have been able, through prudent budget management, to deliver an important incentive to savings.

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Kemp. You should direct your remarks through the chair.

—Through you, Madam President, to Senator Collins: the second point is that you mentioned the evidence before the Senate estimates committee. I would not adopt the habits of some of your colleagues of not actually reading what is said. Don't take a question before you have actually had a chance to read the Senate estimates carefully, read the particular debate there and read fully what the Secretary to the Treasury said. Because this is an important savings measure. This provides an incentive for people to save.

answer.para: And the third point I make, in relation to your imputation that this will largely flow to higher income people, is that the modelling on the savings rebate shows that a substantial proportion of the benefits will actually flow to lower and middle income people. So you have not looked.

We have had questions on this, I would say, for at least a year. I have stood up in this parliament, I am sure, on quite a number of occasions and pointed out this evidence to you, which has never been queried by the Labor Party. Even Senator Sherry, who sort of occasionally knows the odd fact or figure in relation to the economy and the budget, has never been able to get up and knock this particular statistic.

talk.start.para: —I have—I have knocked it constantly.

—No, you have not, Senator. You have tried to, very unsuccessfully. Let me conclude by making these points. This is a very important savings measure. It is welcomed by the vast majority of Australians. Millions of Australians will benefit as a result of this measure. Most of the benefits of the measure will flow to low and middle income people.

answer.para: Senator, you should recognise, and the public will recognise, that we have been able to deliver a savings initiative. The Labor Party, despite all its promises—and perhaps the greatest broken promise since Federation was in 1993—was never able to achieve that. Why do you not, for a change, adopt a constructive approach, recognise that this is an important initiative by the government and, rather than attempt to indulge in puerile knocking, welcome it like the rest of Australia?

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. I did, in fact, follow the Senate estimates discussion on this matter. I ask you if you could table the modelling to which you have referred in your answer. Additionally, I ask: is this the same savings rebate that will give every member of parliament a $450 tax break merely for being in the parliamentary superannuation scheme? Is this the same savings rebate that the Prime Minister felt was such an unfair windfall for the wealthy that he said he would personally refuse it? Will you refuse it, Minister? Is this also the same savings rebate that Senator Parer will be able to rort and ensure that each and every beneficiary of the W.R. Parer family trust will qualify for a $450 savings rebate, which will entitle each of them to a $7,600 per year tax free trust distribution?

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Earlier in proceedings here today in a previous question, you ruled that Senator Kemp had to answer through you. That question then was directed entirely straight at Senator Kemp. I would ask that you rule it out of order. At no stage was it directed through you, Madam President. As such, that question should be ruled out of order, bearing in mind your previous ruling that Senator Kemp himself had to answer the question through the chair.

—You are absolutely right, Senator. Senator Kemp's last answer was directed across the chamber to the questioner. The question was directed back the same way. They both are not complying with the standing orders, and I am being very tolerant about the amount of time I take in pulling people up. But you are correct.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Senator Collins, you and your colleagues—
—Senator, having been reminded of the standing order—

—Through you, Madam President, Senator Collins and her colleagues, with their votes, attempted to defeat the superannuation surcharge in this parliament. Senator Collins, I invite you to stand up after question—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Kemp. You cannot even hear me call you to order because of the noise on the other side. I would ask senators to abide by the standing orders and not make so much noise. All shouting together like that means that no-one in the chamber hears question time and those listening do not either.

—I invite Senator Collins to stand up after question time to indicate the savings that she would have personally made on her superannuation if the Labor Party had been able to defeat the surcharge. I invite you, Senator Collins, to stand up because the assessments are out. What would you have saved if the Labor Party had been able to defeat the surcharge? Stand up and tell this parliament.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Senator Vanstone. I refer the minister to the policy released yesterday by the One Nation Party dealing with multiculturalism and immigration. This policy is clearly discriminatory and, if it were ever to be implemented, would result in major economic and social damage to Australia. So I ask the minister: given that One Nation has now released a policy which is clearly discriminatory and is unequivocal in its proposal to abolish multiculturalism, will the government and, in particular, the Prime Minister now make a clear, simple and unequivocal statement in support of multiculturalism and the prosperity it brings to Australia?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question. Senator, I do not know if you were in the chamber a couple of days ago when Senator Brown asked me a question with respect to one aspect of One Nation's immigration policy, so described. I am not sure that I would give it the credence of calling something like that a policy. Our position on immigration is perfectly clear.

answer.para: This is the party that got rid of the white Australia policy. These are the parties that first welcomed Indo-Chinese refugees to Australia after the Vietnam War, in opposition to the people opposite who did not want this to proceed. There is no question about the coalition's commitment to immigration at all. Frankly, Senator, why anybody tries to continue to give Ms Hanson and her ratbag nonsense collection of policies any publicity, I do not know.

talk.start.para: —My supplementary question is to ask the minister to address the question I asked the first time around and, particularly in light of her answer, to provide her with the opportunity not to give One Nation a platform but to remove that platform by actually having a clear and unequivocal statement from the government in support of multiculturalism. My question related to multiculturalism, not to the immigration program. I would ask the minister whether or not the government and the Prime Minister in particular will now make a clear, simple and unequivocal statement in support of multiculturalism.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —I have two things in response. We would all like some clear and unequivocal statements. Some of us on this side of the chamber would like a clear and unequivocal statement on your immigration policy and what net zero immigration means. Who are you going to lock out? If you are having net zero immigration, you have to lock somebody out, so we want to know how you are going to go about that. As to the matter of multiculturalism, Minnie Itson married Carl Hennings and then they married Mortimers and Tierneys, and that is how you got me. Lucky you. We are a multicultural country.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Pursuant to standing order 74(5), I ask the Minister for the Environment and the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Hill, for an explanation as to why answers have not been provided to questions on notice Nos 1192, 1193 and 1203, which I asked on 13, 14 and 29 May respectively. I will move:

speech.para: That there be laid on the table by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), by no later than 3 July 1998, the answers to questions on notice Nos 1192, 1993 and 1203.

talk.start.para: —You cannot move that. You may ask the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, why certain questions have not been answered, and you should at least listen to his answer first.
—The answer is that I do not know but I will find out.
—Due to that unsatisfactory explanation, I therefore move:

speech.para: That there be laid on the table by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), before the adjournment of the Senate on 3 July 1998, answers to questions on notice Nos 1192, 1993 and 1203.
As late as the day before yesterday, my office again asked Senator Hill for the answers to these questions.

talk.start.para: —Asked me?

—Yes, you—that is, my office asked your office. Senator Hill is responsible for the inaction in his office on this matter. It comes right from the top; it comes from his own failure to act, presumably because these questions are related to the environment.

speech.para: The questions are important. Two of the questions are to do with the marauding impact on the Victorian forest environment of the regional forest agreement system. They were questions asking for explicit assurances about the regional forest agreement in the Central Highlands of Victoria. Two weeks ago, there was a response that one-quarter of one of those questions could not be provided at the time because there was a Victorian public servant away somewhere. There has been no answer since then.

The third question relates to the Basel Convention and the failure of Australia to ratify the important component of that convention which would prevent Australia, along with other OECD nations, from dumping toxic wastes in less well-off countries. We have seen Greenpeace alert the world of the hazardous waste being shipped out of Australia to Hong Kong. It is a despicable situation for Australia to be in, and we are in that situation because of the despicable failure of this minister to ensure that this government brought Australia into line with other enlightened developed countries. But the minister, who sits there reading a book—

talk.start.para: —He's reading the standing orders!

—I am told that it is the standing orders he is reading. Whatever it is, he will need to read fast because the provision in the standing orders is that he has to do more than simply say, `I don't know what is going on in my office.' It seems that he does not know what is going on with his own legislation. We are told that there is important legislation coming before this parliament later today when somebody in his office gets the papers ready. What is that legislation about? It is about more dereliction of duty to the environment. It is about this minister shedding his national responsibilities to the environment through legislation which would deprive future federal governments of the responsibility and the authority which the Hawke government used to save the Franklin and later the Daintree, for example.

speech.para: This minister has been such a comprehensive failure. Despite what I might have had to say about previous ministers, I am afraid they do not measure up to this minister when it comes to his ability to do the environment in. He is head and shoulders above the rest in his failure to be able to address the environment and act responsibly on behalf of the nation. Senator Faulkner looks like an absolute paradigm compared with this minister—

talk.start.para: —Paragon. The expression is paragon of virtue!

—The reality is that this is a serious matter. The minister is not only failing in his duties to the environment but, as we see him rifling through the pages of the standing orders, he is flouting the Senate. He has 30 days in which to answer questions. The standing orders say that he should answer the questions within 30 days. These are mightily important questions which relate to the constituency in Australia who are concerned about the environment, and isn't that everybody? The minister says that himself.

speech.para: The minister is not only flouting his responsibility on the environment and thumbing his nose at Australians who are concerned by the environment; he is flouting the Senate and the standing orders. There is no ostensible reason—and he says he cannot give one himself—as to why he cannot answer these questions and answer them now. He has, through the provision of this motion, been given 24 hours in which to do so. He has got 24 hours to shape up and show some shred or indication of environmental responsibility.

One would have thought that, along with the Democrats, the Greens and the Labor Party, he would have been able to raise some form of celebration about the fact that yesterday was the anniversary of the saving of the Franklin in 1983. He could not even mention it. What did he do today to mark his recognition of that period of environmental gain in this country? He stumbled towards bringing in legislation which is going to do the country's environment out of a responsible voice and presence at a federal level.

For example, today, when Senator Hill was asked on radio what this new legislation would do to protect species threatened with extinction on private lands, he did not know. He ummed and ahed and fiddled and fumbled around, but he did not know. He does not know what is in his own legislation and he does not know how to answer simple questions about important and critical environmental issues. He cannot handle them.

The minister is not a new member of this place. He is the leader of the coalition government in the Senate. His conduct is not just unbecoming, it is derelict. It is unsatisfactory. The minister is a disgrace to his portfolio. It is a disgrace for him to be ostensibly representing, according to his title, the environment of the Australian nation, a nation which holds the environment in great regard. Senator Hill is contemptuous of it, but Australians are not.

Senator Hill is contemptuous of the spirit in Australia which says that we have to do a lot better by the environment. As he has his back turned to you now, Madam President, he turns his back on the Australian people, and he has done so in everything he has done in the period of his failed ministry. I recommend this motion to the Senate. I ask for Senate support to do get this minister to do something responsible. He has failed to meet the standing orders. It is about time he was brought into line. I hope the Senate will help me bring him into line on this matter.

talk.start.para: —Speaking on the motion on Senator Hill's failure to answer a question on notice, we expected Senator Hill to address some of the issues raised by Senator Brown in order for the opposition to make an evaluation as to which way to vote on the motion. We have heard Senator Brown's case. We have heard certain matters raised by Senator Brown, but there has been no response whatsoever from Senator Hill.
—Still open-minded are you, Robert?

—We were open-minded on it because, when Senator Brown first raised the issue, Senator Hill indicated across the chamber that he did not know about it. The normal practice is that, when a senator rises in this place under this particular provision of the standing orders, the senator would give the minister a tip-off a couple of hours beforehand. You do not do that to benefit the minister; you do it to benefit yourself, because it usually sparks in the minister's mind the idea of speeding up the process. Senator Brown, when that process is followed, it is amazing how often an answer will come back very quickly.

speech.para: Senator Hill indicated that he personally had not known that this had been raised. Senator Brown then came in—and I have no reason to disbelieve him—and indicated that he had contacted Senator Hill's office the day before yesterday about these matters. There could have been a breakdown in communication in Senator Hill's office that led to no reason being prepared to give after question time today.

It is this frustration that has caused Senator Brown to move this motion. Although I must say that I am still puzzling over his reference to Senator Faulkner as a `paradigm'. That has me confused, because I understand that a paradigm is an example of a pattern, especially of the inflexions of a noun or a verb. We do not know whether you have insulted our leader—and if you have, we are going to vote this motion down—or whether you have praised our leader—in which case you are in like Flynn with our 28 votes! But we do not know, and we probably will never know.

A long response is not required from Senator Hill to indicate what his position on this has been. I understand from Senator Brown's speech that it has been a considerable period of time since he asked this question, probably much longer than 30 days. Senator Brown has indicated that it was mid to late May, so it is on the edge. In these instances, the complexity of the question that has been asked must be taken into account. It is quite proper for a minister to get up and say that a particular question on notice was extremely complex and extremely difficult to answer. That has been done before. When it is done, I think senators around the chamber should accept that as a relevant excuse.
I should just tell Senator Brown that the 30-day rule was introduced by this side of the chamber against a Labor government. We were not enthusiastic about it at the time, I must say.

talk.start.para: —We are now!

—Yes, a small change in geography has enthused us much more on this particular matter, but we are very disappointed that those on the other side are no longer consistent on this issue. They were passionate believers in the 30-day rule—as they were on the cut-off motion and everything else—until it applied to them, and now they are not so passionate. The 30-day rule has been introduced, essentially, to try to pressure ministers to give answers to questions on notice in a reasonable period of time. It does not exist in the other House. There, matters have to be taken up with the Speaker, the Speaker has to agree to write to the relevant minister, and then a response comes. In the Senate, we have a more economic and automatic provision.

speech.para: In certain cases there are genuine excuses for ministers not being able to respond within 30 days, especially if they have to go into the archival material and if it involves complex and interrelated matters. However, at the very least, what is required when notice is given to a minister's office is that some reasonable explanation be given to the senator concerned as to why questions have not been answered.

Some questions on the Notice Paper have gone beyond the 100 days and have yet to be answered, but senators take into account the complexity of those questions and are very patient. What is required now, other than Senator Hill's contribution before Senator Brown moved the motion, is some sort of explanation as to, for instance, firstly, why the question has not been answered or, secondly, an assurance from Senator Hill that he will chase this matter up and get an answer to Senator Brown by the end of the week. That would mean that Senator Brown could then withdraw his motion.

The Senate has to grapple with the situation where Senator Brown's motion is carried yet physically the answer cannot be got across. If we make an order of the Senate and it is simply impossible for the minister's department, given their stage of work on this question, to answer it properly tomorrow, it might be a matter that we will have to discuss tomorrow. However, one would hope that this series of questions that he put to Senator Hill can be answered by tomorrow and that Senator Brown can benefit from those answers. We should at least give Senator Hill a chance to try to swing the jury on this side by putting up some explanation. We will keep an open mind. I am certain that Senator Faulkner will keep an open mind before he instructs us which way to vote.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ray for giving me the opportunity to get some further and better information on this matter. I can now table an answer to question 1193, which was the question on the ban clause. It was delayed because of a difference of view between my office and the draftsman in the department on one small aspect. It will be a puzzle for Senator Brown to work out at his leisure. The other matter concerned questions 1192 and 1203. I understand that it was addressed to me in my position as the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The answers are still within the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. I am also chasing up that matter. I undertake to get the answer to Senator Brown as quickly as possible. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
MINISTER FOR THE ENVIRONMENT
Senator Brown asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 14 May 1998:
With reference to the Basel Convention and the Basel Ban:

(1) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 896 (Senate Hansard, 30 October 1997, p.8542), in which it was stated that `The Australian Government will make a decision, after appropriate consultation, on whether or not to ratify the ban amendment when the technical aspects of the Basel lists are finalised': now that the new hazardous waste lists have been adopted at the Conference of Parties (4), together with a process for continued improvement of them, has Australia's concern been addressed.
(2) When will the Australian Government start ratification of the Basel Ban, Decision 111/1 of the Basel Convention, into domestic legislation.
(3) Will the Government ban the export of hazardous waste for recycling and recovery to non-annex VII (non-OECD) countries.
Senator Hill— The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(1) At the Fourth Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Basel Convention, or COP 4, adoption of the lists (A and B) of wastes as new annexes (Annexes VIII and IX) to the Convention was a priority for the Australian Government. Decision IV/9's adoption of the lists of wastes provides much greater precision as to the Convention's scope.

Some wastes remain on list C, a list not included in the new Annexes because it contains wastes whose status is yet to be decided. However, because list C is no more than a list of wastes proposed to be considered by the new review mechanism, there will always be some wastes on list C.

However, COP4 also considered amendments to the list of countries in Annex VII. Decision IV/8 provided that no amendments to Annex VII would be made until the ban amendment, Decision III/1, enters into force. It also commissioned the Convention's technical and legal groups to report to the Parties on the issues relating to Annex VII. This means that the scope of Annex VII is not clear and consequently, the implications for implementation of Decision III/1 are not settled and will need to be clarified. This uncertainty remains a concern for the Australian Government which has not been addressed by Basel Convention Parties.

(2) The Australian Government will consider both of these COP4 decisions, through the usual procedures of consultation with stakeholders. It would, of course, be necessary to prepare a National Interest Analysis before any decision was taken to ratify the Basel Ban amendment set out in Decision III/1.

talk.start.para: —Noting that offer by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) and expecting that it means certainly before we rise in this session, I am happy to withdraw the motion. I give notice that it will be back in here again at about this time next week if I do not have an answer by then. I seek leave to withdraw the motion.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Brown asked me a question with regard to capital works spending on the Murray-Darling Basin. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, has provided a detailed response. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

. The decision to fund capital works contributions to the Murray Darling Basin initiative is entirely consistent with the natural resource management objectives of the Natural Heritage Trust as described in Part 3, paragraphs 9 and 17 of the Natural Heritage Trust Act.
. In this light, an additional amount of around $12 million will be provided to the Murray Darling Basin Commission for capital works over the period 1998-99 to 2000-01.

. This funding is to ensure that water regulation structures operate effectively to achieve economic and environmental objectives along the river. Over this period of time it is expected that the water business will be established as a SEPA rate entity and operate in a er consistent with COAG water reform requirements.
. The government's capacity to deliver on the important objectives of the Natural Heritage Trust or the Murray Darling Basin 2001 program is fully secures
. It is important to note that the current federal budget allocates close to $43 million to Murray Darling Basin natural resource management programs.
. This compares to just $13.8 million provided for similar activities in the last year of the Keating government.

. The Howard government's commitment to the environment, natural resource management, and the Murray Darling Basin is an enormous increase on teat provided or promised by the previous government, and confirms once again that the coalition has a track record on environmental matters which the opposition could never compete with.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to a question without notice asked by Senator Jacinta Collins today, relating to savings rebate plan.

talk.start.para: —How much did you save?

—Can I say in response to that silly interjection that I am very disappointed, in taking note of the answer, that Senator Kemp has left the chamber. He asked me at the end of question time, after issuing a challenge, whether I would respond. I responded that I would take note of his answer, but he has left the chamber. He will have to wait to hear how I will deal with the matter he raised. I am still anticipating Senator Kemp's tabling of the modelling that I asked for in my supplementary question. He has not dealt with that issue. Senator Kemp tried to claim some thread of fairness in this measure and referred to modelling. We know not what that modelling is, and he has not indicated any preparedness to table it. I do not really think Senator Kemp should be the one issuing challenges in this sort of matter.

speech.para: His implication that the Labor Party opposed the superannuation surcharge measures on the basis of the personal impact it would apply, for instance, to my superannuation arrangements was very unfair. He knows full well that the reasons we opposed these measures were based, firstly, on the fact that the government had come into office on the claim that it would not increase any taxes. This is obviously a tax. Secondly, there were unfair administrative burdens in this measure that would impact unfairly on low and middle income earners. That was the second reason why the Labor Party opposed this measure.

I want to comment on the broader issues of tax policy. As I said, Senator Kemp referred to the superannuation surcharge. The superannuation surcharge is a tax, as is the savings rebate, and an unfair one at that. The GST is another unfair tax measure. The savings rebate is unfair. Unfortunately, Senator Parer has also left. He sat around for a while after question time. I was hoping that he would remain. I am going to give this measure the Parer award. We now have the Parer award, the Parer test and the Parer principle. The Parer award is granted to Senator Parer, in my mind, because this measure will allow him to further minimise his taxation arrangements.

Let us look at the example of a family of four. By 1999-2000, such a family will be able to structure its affairs in such a way that it will attract a rebate of a mere $2,000. This is only those families that are in a position to be able to structure their affairs that way; it is not the majority of middle and low income families, whose income is predominantly from wages and salaries.

talk.start.para: —And consumed.

—And which is consumed, as Senator Bishop kindly reminds me. The savings rebate is not really a savings rebate. It is a rebate that rewards those with savings related income rather than those who are actually engaged in saving, as my question highlighted. The question also highlighted the cost involved. Treasury and the retirement incomes modelling task force point out that this measure will cost $2 billion by the period 2000-01.

speech.para: The other comment I would like to make on this measure is that it is a pretty weird policy if you look, for instance, at what I highlighted in relation to members of parliament. On the one hand we have the super surcharge being applied to MPs; on the other hand we allow the savings rebate. So we take with one hand and give back with the other. For a government that supports small government, it is difficult to understand why they are introducing measures that will simply burgeon the tax bureaucracy. It does not make sense.

What I highlighted about the Prime Minister is also weird policy. Prime Minister Howard says, `I won't take it.' Why does he say that? Because it is unfair of course. But it is not going to stop his mates taking it. Of course not. Senator Kemp issued a challenge, and that is fair enough; but he stepped away from the question I asked him which was: the Prime Minister says he will not take it; what about you? There was no answer there at all. As I said, this is weird policy.

talk.start.para: —What about you?
—Senator Ferguson asks: what about you? It is not my policy. That is a pretty fundamental point. (Time expired)
—The coalition welcomes the debate about savings policy.
—You haven't got one.

—The Australian Labor Party sure had one. Senator Bishop is clearly proud to be a member of a party that had such a clear record when it comes to national savings. Senator Jacinta Collins is the emerging economic expert in the Senate.
—Don't be so patronising.
—People know that Senator Peter Cook is looking at Geneva; he is looking at the ILO. He is looking at Lake Geneva.
—I've just come back from there.

—Senator Collins has just been there. Maybe she is going to beat Senator Cook to that place. She has this big interest in national savings. The coalition does, too. We compare our record with the record of the Australian Labor Party. They have a very long record in savings that you know well, Madam Deputy President, because you were a part of that government.

speech.para: Senator Bishop interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Bishop, if he was smart, would say, `Look, I wasn't really here when they did all that.' The Australian Labor Party government had a great record. That record should never be forgotten by the Australian people: $12.2 billion a year for 10 years on the trot. They were in government for 13 long years and Senator Jacinta Collins comes in here and says, `We care about national savings.'

speech.para: The record of Labor in 13 years of government was that for 10 of those years they ran deficits. For national savings, they say, `We don't put any money in the bank. We don't save as a nation; we will actually spend $12.2 billion more than we earn as a nation'—year in, year out for 10 years on the hop. Each year they make a decision: are we going to save as a nation this year; what is the government going to contribute to savings? The Australian Labor Party sit down in the cabinet room to discuss the budget and say, `No, we are not; we are going to spend $12.2 billion'—in 1998 dollars—`every year.' They made that decision. They have sat in cabinet for 13 years and they have probably had quite a few mini-budgets along the way.

They made those decisions. They made a cold, hard-edged decision that they were going to put Australia into debt. When we talk about Australia, what do we think of? We really think of her citizens, of the taxpayers. What we should be thinking about is not only the taxpayers of today but of the taxpayers of tomorrow. Perhaps Labor were thinking about them; maybe they weren't.

Kids in school at the moment who are contemplating going into the work force have a much bigger chance now under a coalition government than they did under a Labor government. In fact, when you talk about employment, getting into the work force and paying taxes under Labor, people often say: how did I get into the work force under Labor? In those days, you went to a CES office and you stood in queues for a few hours—queues of hundreds of people—outside bureaucratic, centralised and controlled offices. But what happens now under Senator Ellison's and Dr Kemp's reforms? They go inside, sit down, talk to people and get a job. Labor had a million people outside the tax system, a million people in these long queues. Madam Deputy President, you would remember those huge queues of unemployed people in New South Wales—the Australian Labor Party's army of unemployed standing in queues outside their lovely CES offices.

Let's defend to the death the CES; let's get back to the queues. That is the Labor Party policy. We are talking about savings here today. You do not save by having a queue of a million people standing outside this shrine of the CES that they will die in a ditch to defend. That is what the Labor Party thinks about savings—$12.2 billion a year.

What have we done for low and middle income families in Australia? We have said, `If you save, we'll give you a tax break.' For the first time in Australian history we have actually changed the tax system. Under Labor, it was: if you save, you get hit. If you save and actually earn some interest, you get hit by tax. What do the Liberal's say about savings? We say, `If you save, if your household puts away some money for a rainy day or saves for your kids' education or saves for a deposit on a house, we'll give you a tax break.'

What do Labor say? `We don't like that. That's rude; that's crude. We don't want that; we want to tax you.' That is their tax policy and that is their savings policy. Their savings policy is $12.2 billion a year in debt. Their savings policy is: if you as a household save, if you put a little bit of money away, we will take some tax on that. So on 1 July, for the first time in history, if you are an Australian saver, you will get a tax break. Labor says, `No, that's not good enough for us.' That is the Labor Party's policy. The people will have a choice to make at some stage, and that is the choice. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I also rise to take note of the answer by Senator Kemp to a question raised by Senator Collins. I agree with remarks by previous speakers that the issue of savings is critical to the future of this nation. It affects corporations, individuals and, necessarily, our public sector.

speech.para: Firstly, it is directly related to the current account and the high real domestic interest rates that are needed to attract and retain capital in this country. As we know, over the last two or three years that problem has been getting worse and worse, with the current account blowing out to of the order of $30 billion on current figures. Secondly, it affects the value of the currency and associated movements in the currency markets and, thirdly, it affects trade—trade patterns and trade markets. We only have to look at yesterday's papers to see the impact of the currency. When the trade deficit came in at around $500 million or $600 million, that was received well by currency markets, and the dollar jumped by somewhere between a half a cent and 1½c instantly. So it is both proper and essential to address the savings problem in Australia.

At the outset, what is the government's solution? Firstly, a 7½ per cent rebate from 1 July this year; secondly, an additional 7½ per cent from 1 July 1999; thirdly, it applies to all forms of savings, however derived; and, fourthly, it applies to all income earners.

In summary, we can say that it is unnecessary and wasteful. It is nothing more than a kickback to those who have engaged in past savings—that is, whether it be for savings in banks, personal superannuation, share bonds or income derived from assets. Any form of saving, no matter how worthless or inappropriate, is the subject of reward to the value of $450 per annum.

What does this savings rebate do? It transfers government savings to private consumption. In an era of budget surpluses, it reduces government savings and transfers those savings to members of the public who can engage in spending or consumption. It actually achieves the remarkable result of reducing the total net savings of Australia.

Why is this? It is because it is $450 per individual, $900 per couple and $1,800 for a couple with two dependent children and appropriate financial structures. These recipients have the option of taking that rebate and spending it, so in that sense it is nothing more than a transfer of government savings into private consumption. Not only does it not address encouraging or increasing national savings; as I say, it also actually achieves the amazing result of reducing the total net savings in this country.

We have been told repeatedly in the life of this government over the last two or three years that we need budget balances or surplus budgets. That result has been achieved by limiting growth in outlays in the next few years or by reducing and cutting a whole range of government services. In the last two years, we have had numerous debates about cuts in pensions, child care, education, youth and training and other social entitlements. All of those cuts have been justified on the basis of the need to reduce government outlays as a way of achieving budget balance or budget surplus.

We are told the budget surplus will be something in the order of $2.7 billion up to $10 billion over the next three to four years, and hence we will achieve higher levels of public savings. A significant amount of the entire savings achieved through cuts and cutbacks to public services and community services will be spent or wasted by the offer of this rebate. Most of that rebate will go, as the government well knows—and as it intended in its discussions at estimates—into private consumption, further blowing out the net debt of this country. Even if all or most of that rebate were saved by private individuals, it is only a transfer from public savings to private savings.

So we have a major problem. The government has put forward a flawed solution. It has not put forward any serious policy response to that, and there is no guarantee for the future. We ask the question: why is there this transfer—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, Senator Bishop says that the government has put forward a flawed solution. Can I say to Senator Bishop that he had 13 years but never brought forward any solutions at all to encourage people in Australia to save.

speech.para: This morning I had some kind words to say about Senator Collins's attitude toward a different matter, a report, but I am afraid I cannot continue in the same vein this afternoon. Here we have had Senator Collins talking about a $450 rebate that some people, including members of parliament on this side, would get, yet she is a member of a party—as are Senator Bishop and Senator Murphy—which voted against the 15 per cent surcharge on superannuation. They voted against that in order to save themselves something in the vicinity of $6,000 a year.

Now they have the hide to come in here and say that some members of parliament on this side will perhaps gain a rebate of $450 a year when those opposite tried to vote themselves something in the order of $6,000 a year. That is an outrageous proposition. Senator Collins and Senator Bishop have come in here and criticised the government's performance in trying to encourage savings in this country when they were trying to vote themselves an extra $6,000 a year—

talk.start.para: —Maybe more.

—Maybe more, as Senator Watson says, in some cases. They were determined to line their own pockets and then criticise some people who might get $450. The trouble is that the opposition sees everything through the eyes of a salary and wage-earning PAYE taxpayer, partly because none of them have ever worked for themselves or tried to earn an income or had to save for their own future because there was no-one else doing it for them.

speech.para: What about the hundreds of thousands of people who are self-employed in this country, who in many cases are struggling but who are also wishing to save for the future? The savings rebate which this government introduced yesterday is designed to provide some incentive for particularly those people who are self-employed, for people who have to provide and prepare for their own future, to do so.

It is anticipated that the bulk of the savings rebate will go to individuals who are earning less than $40,000 a year. Not only are we giving them the rebate, but people who are paying up to $1,000 as a personal superannuation contribution, as Senator Bishop knows, will not only get the savings rebate but will also get the existing 10 per cent rebate which is available to people earning up to $31,000. I think that is a marvellous incentive to encourage low income earners to save and to put something away for their retirements. Unlike PAYE taxpayers and wage earners, and those who come under the superannuation guarantee, these people need some incentive to ensure that in retirement they can be self-sufficient.

At no stage have I heard the opposition say what a great benefit this will be for those people who, unlike them, have worked for themselves and battled to earn a living and, in many cases, set up their own businesses. This is an incentive for them to be able to do something for themselves in retirement so that they, when they reach retirement age, will have the possibility of living a lifestyle equivalent to those people who are having an enormous amount put in by their employers in order that they can have a reasonable standard of living when they retire.

What did the opposition do to help low and middle income earners throughout the 13 years they were in government? Absolutely nothing. Their high deficits—the fact that the government had to pay so much extra in interest—and the way the economics of this country operated during those 13 years meant there was absolutely no incentive for low and middle income earners to save. As a matter of fact, it took away one of the very few incentives for people who contributed $3,000 a year to a personal superannuation fund. It took away that right from many self-employed people and wage earners who wanted to supplement their retirement incomes by contributing $3,000. That was a disincentive to people who were trying to provide for their own retirement. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —There were a number of howlers in the last address. It would be fair to say that Senator Ferguson is a good friend of mine, but I have to take him to task on a couple of those howlers. He said a minute ago that all of us on this side of the chamber were miserable because we were trying to get ourselves an extra $6,000 as a result of one of the bills coming through the Senate.
—Or more!

—Or more, he says now. Senator Watson was agreeing. It is no wonder these two are on the backbench. No-one was getting anything out of it. What the government were doing was taking 6,000 bucks off everyone. In fact, stupidly—and I use that word advisedly—they were going to take even more off their own ministers. When they found out about the full impact of this Costello plan, there was a whole string of ministers absolutely spewing over this because they found they would be paying a fortune. They thought that it would be getting all of our old ministers who had retired. That is not what happened.

speech.para: The other thing I want to say—and I will not go too far into it—is that I am handling some representations on this matter for Liberal members of parliament. They do not want to approach their own Assistant Treasurer; they do it through me. I have three of them right now that I have had to take round to good Senator Kemp and say, `Look, Senator Kemp, some of your blokes are not all that happy about this and would like to know about it. Are you really doing this to them?'

I do not want to go into that any further but, then again, I did not open this matter: those opposite did. But if they want to know more about it, all they have to do is talk a bit more about us over here. I am handling no representations for our lot, but I certainly am for theirs. They cannot believe what Costello has done to them. They are not at all pleased about it. A couple of them are even suggesting they might vote for us.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order. Madam Deputy President, I thought you would have pulled up Senator Quirke for not referring to a person in the other place by his correct title.
—That is a very good point of order. Senator Quirke, would you please refer to Mr Costello appropriately and correctly?
—The reverend or the Treasurer?
—The Treasurer.

—Righto. I could have been talking about the reverend. The other howler to come in here was the one that we did absolutely nothing for 13 years about the savings problem in this country. I do not know how anyone could get up and say that with a straight face. We brought in superannuation for all wage and salary earners. We did it over the top of Senator Ferguson's mates. Senator Ferguson now says that we took away the $3,000 limit in which he and a number of others could have participated. We brought in a comprehensive scheme which has pumped, as I understand it, about $400 billion so far into this country's savings.

speech.para: The big problem Australia has is the savings rate and the need for capital because we are a nation of 18 million people in over five million square kilometres. The development of infrastructure and everything else in this country requires a pool of capital. Superannuation, as we brought in over those 13 years—the other day it lifted to seven per cent and is on its way to a higher figure—has been the only success story in what is a very sad story about the question of savings rates in this country. That is the only success story so far to date.

The reality is that this scheme represents nothing more than just a few quid in the back pocket of those people who do not need it. No wonder they think this is such a great idea. It is one of the few paybacks to some of their bigger supporters. It is not much of a payback—there is not that much in it—but it is going to all those people who do not need it. Those opposite stand up in here and make out a case that this is one of the greatest schemes around the place. I honestly have to scratch my head about this government. Of the many things they do, some are just stupid and others are inept—like this scheme.

talk.start.para: —Recently I had the opportunity, as part of the economics committee, of visiting New Zealand for about four days. There I had the opportunity of having dinner with the New Zealand Commissioner for Retirement, and an instructive evening it was. Following that meeting Mr Blair sent me a number of brochures and videos that his office were playing on television outlining the need for New Zealanders to save, and to save a lot more. Perhaps one of the most poignant messages that came out of those videos was from two elderly people, who were not in strong financial circumstances, with the concluding words: `If only I had known then what I know now.'

speech.para: That message illustrates very graphically the need for people, at an early age, to start saving for their retirement. There is something magical about compounding—in putting your money away early in one's working life and contributing regularly over a long period to build up retirement savings. Increasing personal savings is imperative in Australia. Retirement savings must be increased around the world. What Australia needs is a bipartisan attitude towards savings. That is perhaps the second important message that I got from Mr Blair, the New Zealand Commissioner for Retirement.

In New Zealand, there is largely cross-party or bipartisan support for long-term savings. Actuaries tell us retirement savings must be a long-term commitment that must start early in one's working life. I am rather disappointed at the increasing politicisation of retirement savings debate in this country. There will not be a great future for retirement savings unless there is a stable, long-term approach to savings which gives people confidence in putting money aside over a long period so that, in their latter years, they can retire with dignity and with adequate financial support.

Around the world, working patterns are changing quite dramatically. There have also been demographic changes. Many in the work force are changing jobs frequently. Some are retiring a lot earlier than they used to. Jobs for life are gone. But what is important is that people are living a lot longer. Over the long term—and it is not only an Australian problem—economists and demographers tell us that it will be increasingly difficult to provide the sorts of retirement incomes that we have enjoyed in the past.

In some countries, the amount of government support by way of pensions is being reduced. Other countries are raising the age at which people become eligible for retirement incomes. In this country, we certainly have bipartisan support for a lower safety net where low income people become eligible for a government pension. The majority of Australians aspire to something more than a safety net pension. I believe there is a need for both a compulsory and a voluntary approach towards saving. However, voluntary contributions generally require some sort of an incentive.

I am therefore somewhat disappointed at the tone of the debate, which attacked incentives in the form of the recently enacted savings rebate. Admittedly it is not a lot, but it goes a long way for some people in terms of some incentive to provide after tax income for their retirement savings. The federal Liberal government has a good record of encouraging and spreading the opportunities for saving for retirement. I refer, of course, to the recent spouse rebate initiative which encourages a wider spectrum of savings across families and raising the age at which people contribute to their saving.

The USA has provided a number of interesting retirement models. Interest has been shown by a few European countries that have relied heavily on government supported savings arrangements in the form of pensions. The American models that I am referring to rely on the marketplace to provide the mechanism for maximising pension benefits. In other words, one can obtain a better retirement income through relying on investing through the market than through government instrumentalities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 2 July 1998, from Senator Murphy:

interjection.para: Dear Madam President
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The Government's failure to adhere to and implement the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy of 1995 and its lack of policies and interest in preventing the loss of jobs in the forest and paper industry, such as the 250 jobs to be lost at the Burnie Pulp Mill due to Government inaction; and the need for the Government to immediately:

(a) constitute the Wood and Paper Industry Council under its original terms of reference with appropriate funding necessary to enable it to achieve the outcomes contained in the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy;

(b) announce an implementation timetable for the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy with particular attention being paid to the actions that can be taken to further process and value add timber in Australia;

(c) enter into immediate discussions with AMCOR, the relevant trade unions, the Tasmanian Government and the Burnie City Council to determine what actions need to take place to retain the pulp mill in Burnie;

(d) encourage all governments in Australia to recommit to the definition of `ecologically sustainable development' contained in the National Forest Policy statement which was signed by all Australian governments in 1992;

(e) recognise that the Australian community will not tolerate the export of largely unprocessed forest products especially logs and woodchips while our own manufacturing sector is suffering a serious decline and increasing competition from imported products sourced from forests that are not, in any way, managed on an ecologically sustainable basis; and

(f) implement legally available measures to ensure that any wood, pulp or paper products imported into Australia comes from forests that meet applicable and internationally certifiable environmental standards of forest management.
Senator Shayne Murphy
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.
—I move:

speech.para: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The Government's failure to adhere to and implement the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy of 1995 and its lack of policies and interest in preventing the loss of jobs in the forest and paper industry, such as the 250 jobs to be lost at the Burnie Pulp Mill due to Government inaction; and the need for the Government to immediately:

(a) constitute the Wood and Paper Industry Council under its original terms of reference with appropriate funding necessary to enable it to achieve the outcomes contained in the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy;

(b) announce an implementation timetable for the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy with particular attention being paid to the actions that can be taken to further process and value add timber in Australia;

(c) enter into immediate discussions with AMCOR, the relevant trade unions, the Tasmanian Government and the Burnie City Council to determine what actions need to take place to retain the pulp mill in Burnie;

(d) encourage all governments in Australia to recommit to the definition of `ecologically sustainable development' contained in the National Forest Policy statement which was signed by all Australian governments in 1992;

(e) recognise that the Australian community will not tolerate the export of largely unprocessed forest products especially logs and woodchips while our own manufacturing sector is suffering a serious decline and increasing competition from imported products sourced from forests that are not, in any way, managed on an ecologically sustainable basis; and

(f) implement legally available measures to ensure that any wood, pulp or paper products imported into Australia comes from forests that meet applicable and internationally certifiable environmental standards of forest management.

This is a very important urgency motion because the industry which the motion is about is currently on its knees, and it is on its knees because this government, since winning office, has not followed through on the commitments it gave prior to the last election. The industry is on its knees because the government has not followed a strategy that we put in place in 1995, despite the fact that the industry minister, Mr `Black Jack' Moore, said—
Senator Watson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Watson!
—and I quote from a letter dated 17 July 1996 in which the minister said:

speech.para: The government has endorsed the Strategy—
this is the wood and paper industry strategy that Senator Watson is singing out about; it will be very interesting to see how you vote at the end of the day, Senator Watson—
which includes a $38 million package to promote development of internationally competitive wood and paper industries based on ecologically sustainable management practices.

The Strategy is complementary to the development of Regional Forest Agreements and the Forest Industry Structural Adjustment Package, which will create resource security for the industry and facilitate restructuring. It will help to create a stable policy environment, allowing industry to confidently plan and invest in value added activities.
The Government recognises the importance of effective communication between all stakeholders and to this end is currently reviewing the consultative arrangements covering the major forest issues.

Details are expected to be finalised in the near future and once the new arrangements are put in place I am sure that they will ensure the wood and paper industry makes a significant contribution to the future economic development of Australia.

In so far as the industry is concerned, the only thing this government has succeeded in achieving is a 40 per cent increase in export woodchips. How many jobs have we lost? Thousands. How many paper mills have we lost? Indeed, we are looking down the barrel of another pulp mill closing. How many new ones have we seen? Zip.

What did the minister do about the strategy—and the Wood and Paper Industry Council that was supposed to drive it? He scrapped it. He threw the strategy out the window on the one hand and cancelled the Wood and Paper Industry Council. It was not until a disallowance motion in the Senate with respect to woodchip regulations that we were able to get it reinstated. That is what happened; it took us to get it reinstated. Of course, it was never reinstated in its proper form. It was never provided with any funding. Since it was reconstituted in a different form, it has met but twice and cancelled another meeting. It has served as a mechanism for driving absolutely nothing. The executive summary of the wood and paper industry strategy of 1995 says:
The Wood and Paper Industry Strategy is a four year Commonwealth initiative to encourage investment, value adding and jobs growth.
Investments of between $4 billion and $6 billion are at present under consideration. Industry and unions predict between 15,000 and 25,000 . . . jobs over the next decade.
How wrong they were.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I heard Senator Calvert, and obviously I will hear from Senator Abetz. I can recall the Prime Minister talking about the regional forest agreement and what it has done. We know what the Prime Minister and the Premier said when they signed the RFA in Tasmania: `One thousand to 1,500 new jobs.' How many do we have? Absolutely zip. The wood and paper industry strategy says in the executive summary:

speech.para: In implementing the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy, the Government will provide a further $38 million to work with the industry and its workforce to take full advantage of emerging investment opportunities. The Strategy will provide a stable government policy environment in which the industry can plan and invest with minimum risk and maximum confidence. Seizing these investment opportunities will generate import replacement, increased export earnings—
The original terms of reference for the Wood and Paper Industry Council were:
. to advise the Government on the implementation and further development of the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy;
. to promote job creation, industry development, value adding opportunities and investment initiatives; including at the enterprise level; and
. to act as an agent of change in the industry until Regional Forest Agreements are finalised and implemented.

What has this government done? We rightly call upon the government. When this last occurred, when we forced this government to take one little step—albeit a failing step— towards doing something for the industry, when they set up a wood and paper industry forum of no use, Senator Harradine said that he would keep an eye on it. You only got Senator Harradine's vote at that time because you made a promise to do something, which you have not done. On this occasion, I hope that Senator Harradine will vote in the interests of the workers and in the long-term interests of this industry.
What happened when the Burnie mill closed? Who did the government send down? They did not send `Black Jack' Moore down there.

talk.start.para: —Would you please refer to the minister by his correct title, Senator Murphy.
—Mr `Black Jack' Moore.
—His correct title.
—The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr `Black Jack' Moore.
—Senator Murphy!

—The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr Moore, who is known as `Black Jack', he did not go down. Who did they send? They sent the Minister for Social Security. They offered a few hundred thousand dollars and said, `Workers, we're sorry about your plight, but you'll just have to go.' Mr Fahey, who was all aghast at the fact that there was so much resilience in the community, said, `Oh dear, we'll go back, we'll make the company open their books and we'll speak to them real strong. That's what we'll do.'
—Sternly.

—Yes, sternly. Has he done it? No. What else has the government done? The Prime Minister, in a meeting with the workers representatives, the Burnie delegation which came up here last week, said, `We'll make a big announcement.' Well, not too many announcements have come out of the Prime Minister's office.

speech.para: Prior to the last election, in giving a commitment to Alec Marr and a few greenies in the bush, this Prime Minister said that he would reduce export woodchips. You have failed again, Prime Minister. It was obviously not a core promise. He has not reduced export woodchips. Indeed, he has increased them by 40 per cent.

I go again to the last point of this urgency motion, which calls on the government to implement legally available measures to ensure that any wood or paper products imported into this country come from forests which are managed on an ecologically sustainable and certifiable basis.

Of course, I am going to hear from government senators opposite that that cannot be done. They are very silent about that. But I will listen with interest to what they have to say—because I note that they are all Tasmanians—to see whether or not they are prepared to stand up for the workers in Tasmania, let alone the rest of Australia. I hope that they have some determination—I could say something else but I will not—to take some steps that will ensure that this country has, in future, a downstream processing industry in forest based industries, and that we set out on a course of a huge import replacement program, because imports in this country have doubled since 1992. I say to Senator Watson, through you, Madam Deputy President, that they have doubled in the last two years because of the inaction of this government and its failure to do anything in the interests of an industry that does require intervention from a government.

talk.start.para: —Isn't it ironic that the Labor Party should be attempting to blame the coalition government for the shutdown of a pulp mill and for the lack of major investment in a pulpmill? It is as if by implication it believes that, if it were in government, it would be investing billions of taxpayers' dollars itself in that industry. What nonsense. All that governments can do is to remove the impediments to people investing. We are talking about an international commodity industry.
—Leave it to the market.
—I would like to know how else you are going to do it.
—We got more exports from woodchips and logs than you lot.

—Isn't it ironic that the Labor Party is endeavouring to criticise this government for inaction? It is this government that has removed one of the major impediments to investment in this industry in this nation—and, in particular, in Tasmania—by removing uncertainty over the future of the forests. The Labor Party deliberately played green politics with it over a period of 13 years and, as a consequence, frightened investment away from the industry and lost the only genuine opportunity that Australia had for a world-class Kraft eucalypt pulp mill—it was blown—and we will have to wait for that opportunity to arise again.

speech.para: In north-west Tasmania those pulp and paper mills have basically been in trouble. Why? Because, going back a long period of time, previous owners did not take the trouble to upgrade their facilities to meet international competition and to become internationally competitive. They did not do that. But when they did make their first major attempt to do so with the Wesley Vale pulp mill proposal in the late 1980s, what happened? We had the ALP federal government playing green politics with suburban Melbourne and Sydney, against the forest industry throughout the nation, and it killed that project dead. Who killed that project dead? Former minister Graham Richardson killed that project dead. That is basically what happened. It was the only opportunity for a major investment in that industry at that time.

It is important for those listening and for the Senate to understand that the pulp and paper industry is a commodity industry. It requires huge investments. For a greenfield mill we are talking about a minimum of $500 million up to $1 billion or $1½ billion. Investment in the industry is a cyclical business.
