If the government is serious about having renewable energy sources taken up in the bush—where in many areas there is not access to electricity grids and where we are talking about small power usage units such as farms, stations and the like, rather than mining camps, for example, that have a significant need for power and which might in some respects be catered for by the government's response—and if the rural producers operating in regional and remote Australia are going to take up this option then they need to be provided with up-front financial assistance to overcome the impediment—the comparatively high capital cost—to the implementation of these sorts of schemes.

It is true that, if the schemes are taken up and assistance is given, jobs will be created in rural and regional Australia, potentially in the manufacturing of these systems as well as in their installation and maintenance. There is potential for the generation of jobs in rural and regional Australia by the promotion of the use of renewable energy systems. But the view of the committee is that this is not going to happen unless there is some up-front financial assistance provided to primary producers in rural and regional Australia, in particular, so that they have the wherewithal to take up this option which delivers an outcome for the government in its greenhouse gas reduction strategy.

I believe it would be important for this Senate to further consider this matter. Obviously it is a matter for Senator Brown whether he seeks to introduce further legislation and whether he deals with it in the same fashion. The reality, frankly, is that unless this issue is picked up by the major parties, as is suggested by the report endorsed by both sides of this committee, we will simply be talking about this issue and not doing anything about it. That is the problem with the government's response. It does not look like it is willing to pick up this issue. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I present the government response to the following reports: Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies—Reports on R-rated material on pay TV: Parts 1 and 2 and Review of the guidelines for the classification of film and videotapes and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Senator J Ferris
Chair
Senate Select Committee on Information Technologies
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Ferris
I refer to the reports of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies ('the Committee') entitled:
. Report on R-rated Material on Pay TV Part 1 (tabled in the Senate on 9_February 1995); and
. Report on R-rated Material on Pay TV Part 2 and Review of the Guidelines for the Classification of Film and Videotapes (tabled in the Senate on 17 October 1996).

I also refer to your letter of 25 May 1998 in which you advise that the terms of reference of your Committee include receiving and considering outstanding Government responses to the reports of the Committee.

I note that the previous Government did not respond to the Committee's Part 1 Report. Although the response to that Report is long overdue, I set out below, for completeness, the Government's response to each of the Committee's recommendations in both the Part 1 and Part 2 Reports.

para.inline: Recommendation 1: The Committee, having regard to the following matters:
(i) the community's concerns about the levels of violence in the media, especially depictions of sexual violence, and of realistic and degrading, demeaning or exploitative sexual material;
(ii) the contradictory views expressed about the effects of such depictions on attitudes and anti-social behaviour; and
(iii) the lack of clarity of the R classification which permits an excessively broad range of material to be permitted within its definition;
recommends that R-rated material be not permitted on pay TV.

speech.para: See response to recommendation 1 in the Committee's Part 2 Report.

para.inline: That the Office of Film and Literature Classification undertake a comprehensive overhaul of the R classification to define with greater precision the criteria to be used in rating violent, sexually violent, realistic and degrading, demeaning or exploitative sexual material, taking into account its intensity and extensiveness, to ensure its appropriateness for viewing in the home environment.
When the Attorney-General has tabled a revised R classification, the Committee will reconsider its recommendation.

speech.para: The Commonwealth, State and Territory co-operative censorship legislative scheme has been revised since the Report was tabled. The revised scheme commenced on 1 January 1996 with the commence ment of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 (the Act).

Under the Act, classification guidelines approved by Ministers are required to be gazetted and, by inter-governmental agreement, to be tabled in Commonwealth, State and Territory Parliaments. Further amendments to the classification guidelines require the unanimous approval of participating Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers.
During 1995, the Commonwealth, State and Territory Censorship Ministers implemented a full review of the Classification Guidelines for Films and Videotapes (the guidelines).
The review commenced in September 1995. Advertisements calling for submissions from the public were placed in all major National, State and Territory newspapers on 14 and 21 October 1995.

The previous guidelines and a draft of revisions for discussion were sent to all members of Commonwealth, State and Territory Parliaments, to 403 members of the film and related industries, to 338 members who had responded to the advertisements, to 67 previously recorded complainants to the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) and to 30 community organisations.

In total, 146 submissions from members of the public, community groups and industry bodies were received by the OFLC. Two submissions were received from members of the NSW Parliament and, as you will be aware, a joint submission from your Committee.
In summary:
. 66% of submissions expressed concerns about the portrayal of violence
. 53% of submissions expressed concerns about the portrayal of violence and sex on television
. 20% of submissions expressed support for the work of the Board
. 15% of submissions expressed the view that standards had become too lax
. 8% of submissions expressed the view that standards had become too strict.

The submissions were scrutinised by Professor Peter Sheehan, an independent person with expertise in the classification area, who is Pro Vice Chancellor and Head of Post-Graduate Research at the University of Queensland, and by Dr Judith Bowey, a language expert also from the University of Queensland. Professor Sheehan's and Dr Bowey's recommendations were incorporated into a revised draft of the guidelines.

The revised draft guidelines were unanimously endorsed by Commonwealth, State and Territory Censorship Ministers on 11 July 1996. They were tabled in the Senate on 31 October 1996 and in the House of Representatives on 30 October 1996.

The revised guidelines have tightened standards applied to the classification of violence, and particularly sexual violence, in films and videotapes. Depictions of violence which are excessive and previously warranted a `high level violence' consumer advice in the `R' classification are now classified `RC' (refused classification).
The response to recommendations 2 to 9 has been endorsed by all Censorship Ministers.

Recommendation 1: That the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 be amended to define with greater precision the manner in which reception of subscription narrowcasting services is to be limited under section 17 of the Act, by removing section 17(a)(v) so as to prevent the broadcast of R-rated and X-rated material through the medium of Subscription Broadcasting Services (Pay TV).

The Government has reviewed the adequacy of current provisions in the Broadcasting Services Act regarding X and R-rated material on pay television and decided to extend the prohibition on X-rated material, and any replacement category, to all narrowcasting services and to prohibit R-rated material on open narrowcasting services. R-rated material will continue to be prohibited on subscription broadcasting services.

Pay television providers who have canvassed the possibility of providing an X-rated narrowcasting service will be limited to providing R-rated narrowcasting programming. The Television Subscription Narrowcasting Code of Practice, which was registered with the Australian Broadcasting Authority in September 1997, restricts access to R—rated material to those with appropriate disabling devices and restricts services devoted predominantly to adult erotica to late night access only.

The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997, which contains the Government's proposed amendments in relation to X and R-rated material on narrowcasting services, has been passed by both Houses of the Parliament.
The Government is also considering the Committee's latest report: Report on the Portrayal of Violence in the Electronic Media.

Recommendation 2: That the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 should be amended to make amendments of the National Classification Code under section 6 and determinations or amendments of the classification guidelines under section 12 to be disallowable instruments by the Commonwealth Parliament.

The Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 (the Act) is the Commonwealth's contribution to a revised co-operative Commonwealth, State and Territory censorship scheme which came into effect on 1 January 1996.

The Act is based on the Australian Law Reform Commission's (ALRC) Report on Censorship Procedure . The ALRC was required to report on how Australia's censorship laws could be made more simple, uniform and efficient, while preserving the co-operative nature of the then current scheme. Censorship is an area where the Commonwealth does not have comprehensive Constitutional power.

The Act reflects the ALRC's preferred option for reform. It is a federal Act for the ACT which establishes the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board and sets out the procedures for the making of classification decisions. The complementary State and Territory legislation picks up decisions made under the Act for the purposes of enforcement in their respective jurisdictions.

To give effect to this scheme it was necessary for the States and Territories to voluntarily give up some of their legislative powers, in particular their power over the procedures under which classification decisions are made.

An integral part of the ALRC's recommended approach was a classification code agreed to by the Commonwealth, States and Territories which would contain the classification categories and criteria. In commenting on this the ALRC notes (in paras 2.12 and 2.13, respectively of its Report) that:

"The classification categories and criteria, however, would not be legislated by any State or Territory, nor by the Commonwealth. Instead, they would be, as they are at present, agreed to by the States, the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth. They would form a `code'. An agreement between governments would include provision for amendment of the code from time to time. The classifying body would be instructed by the federal Act to make decisions in accordance with the terms of the agreed code as in force for the time being. The text of the code as it stood when the federal law was enacted would be published for information as a schedule to the federal Act. The schedule would not, however, be part of the Act."

"This alternative [i.e. the preferred option] accurately reflects, and maintains, the balance of responsibilities that has been arrived at between these jurisdictions. It recognises that, in relation to the classification criteria and categories, the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory [and following a decision of Ministers, the ACT] are equal partners, and that policy on these matters is derived from agreement between all the jurisdictions. There will be a single procedure, avoiding the overlaps and duplications that presently exist, and the classifiers will derive their powers from a single source, removing the difficulty that they sometimes face now of conflicting legislation from different jurisdictions. Provision will need to be made for amendments to the code to be published."
The code referred to is the National Classification Code (the Code) set out in the Schedule to the Act, which was agreed to by all jurisdictions.

Classification decisions under the Act are also to be made in accordance with the classification guidelines and the comments made in relation to the Code are equally applicable to the determination and amendment of those guidelines.
There are clear benefits to the industry and the Australian community from the much simplified and more uniform scheme reflected in the revised scheme.

During the passage of the Commonwealth Bill, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills drew attention to the fact that it enables the Code to be amended by the agreement of Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers without reference to the Parliament. The Committee's report includes an extract from the former Attorney-General's response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on this matter. He noted that the Commonwealth conducted its negotiations with the States and Territories on the basis of the ALRC's recommended legislative approach and the concern expressed by some States and Territories that, having agreed to forego legislative power in certain areas, particularly in relation to the classification categories and criteria, subsequent agreements reached on these matters could be undone by the Federal Parliament. He also drew attention to the fact that there is often a need for some compromise to achieve co-operation between Australian Governments.
This question was also addressed by the Committee in its November 1994 Report on the Consideration of the Provisions of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994 .

In that Report the Committee recommended that the classification guidelines and amendments to the Code and classification guidelines be tabled in both Houses and that State and Territory Ministers be urged to do likewise in their respective Parliaments.

The former Government agreed with these recommendations, as did all State and Territory Ministers. This requirement (under which any agreement to amendments to the Code and guidelines must be unanimous) is now reflected in the inter-governmental agreement relating to the revised scheme.

A key feature of the ALRC's recommendations was that amendments to the Code and the guidelines should be subject to a public consultation process. This has also been endorsed by all Censorship Ministers and is reflected in the inter-governmental agreement.

The public consultation process that was undertaken for the computer games guidelines in 1993/94 and the recent extensive consultation on the revision of the films guidelines gave ample opportunity for all sections of the Australian community to have input into the content of these guidelines. I note that comments were also sought from the Committee and its members as part of the film guidelines review.
Further, the requirement to table amended guidelines and the amended Code in all Australian Parliaments gives the opportunity for Parliamentarians to debate the content of these documents.

The Government is of the view that these procedures strike an appropriate balance between preserving the revised co-operative scheme, with the benefits it bestows on the industry and the community, and the need to provide adequate safeguards to ensure that amendments to the Code and the guidelines adequately reflect community views.

In this context, the current position under the new scheme should be contrasted with the position that existed under the previous scheme. Under that scheme few jurisdictions recognised, legislatively, the existence or role of the classification guidelines in making classification decisions and there was no requirement for a public consultation process in amending the guidelines.

In view of the above, the Government is not convinced of the need to make amendments to sections 6 and 12 of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 as recommended by the Committee.

para.inline: Recommendation 3: That the current position of Director of the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) be re-styled as the Chief Executive Officer of the OFLC and that there be new positions of Director and Deputy Director of the Classification Board to be appointed from the community representatives on the Board.

speech.para: This recommendation carries with it the implication that the current position of Director of the Classification Board precludes the occupant being considered to be a representative of the community like other Board members. If implemented it would also appear to remove any managerial duties from the Deputy Director's position.

Under the Act, the statutory positions of Director and Deputy Director are subject to the same appointment processes as other Board members, i.e. the need to ensure that appointees are broadly representative of the Australian community and the requirement to consult about the appointments with State and Territory Ministers. Further, the positions are filled on merit following the selection of suitable candidates after public advertisements.

The Director and Deputy Director are thus intended to be just as representative of the community as other Board members. The only difference is that in selecting persons to fill these positions regard is had not only to their suitability as representatives of the community in performing classification functions, but also to their capacity to represent the public face of the Board and to their managerial expertise. These latter attributes do not conflict with their community representative role.
In addition to their classification functions, the Director and Deputy have administrative, policy and managerial roles in the running of the Office of Film and Literature Classification.

The OFLC is a small office and it is quite appropriate and cost effective for the Director to also fulfil the function of Chief Executive Officer. As the OFLC exists to provide administrative support to the Classification Board, the introduction of a new Chief Executive Officer position appears to be unwarranted, unnecessary and inefficient during a period of cost restraint and pressure to improve efficiency as the OFLC moves onto a user pays cost recovery basis. The proposal is difficult to justify when the current arrangement provides for the effective management and administration of the affairs of the Classification Board.
The Government's view is that the current structure provided in the Act is an appropriate model.

para.inline: Recommendation 4: That a community committee be established, representing major interest groups such as parents, teachers, churches, academics, women, youth, aboriginal and ethnic representatives:
(a) That the community committee would be asked to consider:
. any decisions of the Classification Board in relation to the release of a film or video with an MA or R rating about which the Board was not unanimous; and

. any decision of the Review Board to vary a Board decision to refuse to release, or release a film or video with a recommended R or MA rating at a lower classification, than recommended by the Board.
(b) that the Review Board be required to take the community committee's recommendations into account in its deliberations, and

(c) that the Attorney-General be required to make a determination on any decision of the Review Board to release a film or video at a lower classification than approved by the unanimous decision of the Board, and be required to take into account the community committee's recommendations.

speech.para: In its October 1993 Report on Video and Computer Games and Classification Issues and its November 1994 Report on the Consideration of the Provisions of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994 the Committee recommended the establishment of a community committee, which it saw `as a means of assuring the general community that the voting system on both Boards did not lead to the oppression of a sizeable minority by a slim majority'.
I note this recommendation was rejected by the previous Government with the support of State and Territory Censorship Ministers.

I am informed that one of the factors that led to the Committee first recommending a `community committee' was the decision taken by the then Film and Literature Board of Review to release the film Salo on appeal from the then Censorship Board's decision to retain the longstanding ban on its release. This decision was, however, taken in 1992 and much has changed since then. The fact that concern is expressed by some about one particular decision among the many thousands that have been made both before and since does not, in my view, lead to the conclusion that the system under which classification decisions are made is flawed.

In its latest report the Committee calls `for a restructuring of the OFLC to make it more reflective of community standards'. It also considers that establishment of a community committee, in conjunction with a review of the composition of the two Boards and the continuation of the OFLC's program of research into community standards `should lead to more appropriate classification decisions'.

The assertion that the Boards are delivering `inappropriate' classification decisions is not supported by the evidence provided by research, by analysis of complaints received by the OFLC, or submissions received from members of the public during the recent review of the guidelines for the classification of films and videotapes.

Figures provided by the Motion Pictures Distributors Association of Australia show that 69.9 million cinema tickets were sold during 1995 and figures provided by the Australian Visual Software Distributors Association show that 13.5 million videos were sold over the same period, of which 3.3 million were sold to video rental businesses. During 1995-96 the OFLC received a total of 255 complaints, of which 41 (16%) related to cinema films, 20 (8%) related to videos, 158 (62%) related to publications and 36 (14%) related to television programs over which the Board has no authority.

There is no legislative requirement that there be unanimity in Classification Board decisions (or for that matter decisions of the Review Board) and nor should there be. For most significant decisions, a panel of at least three Board members is involved, although more problematical material may be referred to the whole Board for decision. Many Board decisions are made on a majority vote. This is not surprising, given the diversity in views about censorship that exists within the community that the Board members represent.

Under the new censorship legislative scheme, questions relating to whether Board decisions reflect community standards have been addressed by providing that the membership of the Boards be broadly representative of the Australian community and that members remain abreast of community attitudes.

As the Committee notes in its Report, the Ministerial Committee on the Portrayal of Violence in the Media recommended that the Commonwealth Attorney-General should review the composition and terms of appointment of members of the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board.

It does not follow from this, as the Committee suggests, that the `Commonwealth Government is not confident that the subsequent reforms introduced in the Classification Act have been a success'. It does, however, afford an appropriate opportunity to review the appointment processes and the current composition of the Boards to ensure that the requirement in the Act `that regard is to be had to the desirability of ensuring that the membership of the Board[s] is broadly representative of the Australian community' is being met.
The issue of ensuring that the Classification Board's membership remains representative has been addressed in a number of ways.
Appointments to the Board follow public advertisement, interviews and recommendations on the basis of merit. A representative of the States and Territories sits as a member of the interviewing panel.

Further, there is now a requirement in the Act that State and Territory Censorship Ministers be consulted on all appointments. This consultation process is treated seriously by all Censorship Ministers.

There is criticism from time to time from a variety of sources that this process does not result in a Board membership of sufficient diversity in background and qualifications to adequately meet the requirement of a membership that is broadly representative of the Australian community.
While there may be some merit in this argument it does not follow that Board decisions can be said, as a consequence, not to reflect community standards.
However, I decided that the actual selection process itself should be reviewed to see if it requires modification in order to attract a more diverse range of suitable applicants.
This review has now been completed and the results will be reflected in the next selection round for appointments to the Board which will take place in the near future.
As to keeping abreast of community attitudes, the ALRC's recommendation for an on-going public consultation program has been implemented by the OFLC.

Additionally, the OFLC regularly commissions research into community attitudes about classification issues and the adoption of new entertainment technologies in the Australian community. Some of this research is commissioned jointly with the Australian Broadcasting Authority. Recent studies include Computer Games and Australians Today , Families and Electronic Entertainment and a review on the effects of playing computer games on young people.

Notwithstanding the above factors, the Government acknowledges that concerns are expressed from time to time about whether some of the Board's decisions can be considered to reflect general community standards.
The Government considered, therefore, that there was merit in putting in place some form of external community assessment process to assist classifiers in their work.
Accordingly, in December 1996, I announced a proposal to establish Community Assessment Panels to ensure a greater community input into the classification of films and videos.
The proposal was endorsed by State and Territory Censorship Ministers at a meeting on 14 March 1997.
The panels will help make film classification decisions representative of the broader Australian community by maintaining awareness of community standards.

Panels will comprise up to 20 members who will be drawn from a broad cross section of the community. They will represent various age groups and diverse backgrounds. There will be three panels established in the first 12 months of the scheme.

The panels will have an advisory role in assessing classifications made by the Classification Board and will be reporting both to the Board and to Censorship Ministers. This will enable the Ministers to monitor community involvement in the classification of films and videos and the extent to which the Board's decisions reflect general community standards.
The panels will not delay the classification process by imposing an extra tier of decision making.

Independent consultants will select the members of the panels and will facilitate the reporting by the panel. The first panel has now met in Sydney, the second in Brisbane and the third in Wagga Wagga.

Censorship Ministers have recommended that the panels be constituted in different jurisdictions throughout Australia as the scheme proceeds so that they will be able to properly assess community views throughout all parts of Australia.
The cost of running the panels will be met from within the budget of the Office of Film and Literature Classification.

para.inline: Recommendation 5: That the Classification Board launch, as a matter of high priority, a program of recall and reclassification of material in all classifications where the new guidelines suggest that a higher classification is warranted.

speech.para: While the Government supports, in principle, reclassifying certain films where this is warranted as a result of changing community standards, or the introduction of a new classification such as the MA category in 1993, it considers that, from a practical point of view, this should be restricted to films which have been the subject of a complaint.

In this context, the possible reclassification of stronger M films classified prior to the introduction of the MA category in 1993 was considered by Censorship Ministers at their meeting on 25 October 1996.

For this purpose, the Office of Film and Literature Classification conducted an initial audit of video titles classified M between July 1991 (the codification system employed in the search commenced at that time) and May 1993. This revealed that a total of 1172 (or 18.3%) of video titles were classified at the M level during the period. Of these, 58 contained high level M violence. This represents 4% of titles classified M during the period and 0.9% of the total number of titles classified during the period.
The search only included video titles as there are unlikely to be pre-1993 cinema films still in circulation. Films of this vintage are likely to have been distributed on videotape.

Of the 58 titles identified as containing high level M violence, none, as far as could be ascertained, had been the subject of complaints nor, according to the Australian Visual Software Distributors Association, were they titles in high demand. Further, in some cases, the distributors of these films may have changed or gone out of business, rendering the wholesale reclassification of such films impractical.
In the light of the above factors, Ministers unanimously agreed that pre-1993 M films would be recalled for reclassification on a case by case basis and on receipt of a complaint.

The revised guidelines reflect some changes in community attitudes, particularly in the area of violence and sexual violence. The Committee is now suggesting that any film which may warrant a higher classification under the revised guidelines should be recalled for reclassification.

If this approach was to be implemented, each time there was a perceived change in community standards it would be necessary for the Classification Board to spend very significant amounts of time and resources attempting to identify films from the past to see whether they would warrant a re-classification on this basis. Older films do not generally enjoy a wide circulation or high popularity. Most popular films disappear from the 100 top films lists, which are compiled by industry bodies, within 2 years of release (films cannot be reclassified within 2 years of the initial decision). The level of complaint about specific titles follows this trend.

In these circumstances, the Government does not consider it is either practicable or necessary to try to undertake an extensive reclassification. However, as with certain pre-1993 M films, it does consider it appropriate to consider a reclassification if complaints are made about a particular film. This would include older films that are re-released.

para.inline: Recommendation 6: That the film and video guidelines for each of the categories be amended to explicitly state that the classifiers must take account of community concerns about the portrayal of persons in a demeaning manner.

speech.para: The National Classification Code states as a principle that classification decisions are to give effect, as far as possible, to ". . . the need to take account of community concerns about . . . the portrayal of persons in a demeaning manner."

This principle applies to all classification decisions, as the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 requires such decisions to be made in accordance with the Code. The principles are also formally included in the revised classification guidelines which were approved by Censorship Ministers on 11 July 1996, being set out in full on page 3 of these guidelines.
The issue of the portrayal of persons in a demeaning manner was also taken into account in formulating the revised guidelines for each of the classification categories.

The Government's view is that classifiers are already required to take account of community concerns about the portrayal of persons in a demeaning manner and that additional references as suggested by the Committee are unnecessary.

Censorship Ministers are, however, considering this matter in the context of the classification guidelines for the proposed new `NVE' classification to be created on abolition of the `X' Classification.

para.inline: Recommendation 7: That separate guidelines be introduced for the classification of videotapes to ensure that higher standards are applied than for the equivalent categories of film for cinema release.

speech.para: The Government does not support this recommendation.

The Government's Law and Justice policy for the March 2 election states that it will ". . . work with States and Territories in pursuit of clear standards for film, television, literature, computer and video games, audiotext and bulletin boards that operate to prevent the excessive portrayal of violence or obscenity."
Current policy sets the film and video criteria at identical thresholds.

Research reveals that there is clear support for the idea of having a similar classification scheme operating for television, film and video (79%). There are persuasive arguments that the system should continue in its present form to promote community understanding of, and confidence in, the classification process and to provide business certainty on a national basis.

The situation already exists where a free-to-air TV M, a film and video M and a computer game M may differ. Considerable consumer confusion is likely to follow if further differences are introduced, for example, a difference in content between a video M and a cinema M. This is particularly so as the content is invariably the same and the video version is usually released shortly after the end of the cinema season.

The Act also makes provision for consumer advice giving information about the content of films and videos. This enables adults and, in particular parents, to make informed choices about what they view and allow their children to view.

The hire or purchase of a video involves a conscious choice by a person. In relation to denying access by children to unsuitable material so obtained, this is a matter which falls directly into the area of parental responsibility. There are definite limits to what Governments can do or be expected to do in controlling what occurs in individual homes.

The fact that some parents may act in what some may consider to be an irresponsible manner in this area is not an adequate excuse for curtailing the availability of material to adults generally (which could be the case if `R' rated material is to be classified at a higher threshold for videos) or parents who do act responsibly.

para.inline: Recommendation 8: That the Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers regularly discuss and review enforcement procedures in relation to the sale, hire, distribution and display of film and video material.

speech.para: The enforcement of the national classification scheme is the responsibility of the States and Territories. Commonwealth, State and Territory Censorship Ministers meet regularly and discuss a variety of issues which include issues relating to the enforcement of the national classification scheme.

Censorship Ministers have considered problems of non-compliance with the legislative requirements following the commencement of the national classification scheme in January 1996. Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, Western Australia, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory have agreed to participate with the Commonwealth in an educational scheme to assist distributors and retailers to meet their legal obligations under the national classification scheme.
The Community Liaison Officer scheme commenced in February 1997 for an initial trial period of twelve months.

para.inline: Recommendation 9: That the OFLC's reviews of the guidelines for the classification of publications and computer games should be conducted in a publicly accountable manner, including through the involvement of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies.

speech.para: Censorship Ministers approved a sequential review of the classification guidelines for films and videotapes (now complete), and publications and computer games. In so doing, Censorship Ministers approved a review process which includes extensive public consultation and expert input.

The Committee was closely involved in the review of the Classification Guidelines for Films and Videotapes. All members received the guidelines package which was distributed for public comment. In lieu of providing a submission to the review, the Committee chose to hold a hearing with Mr Reaburn and OFLC senior statutory officers in November 1995. A second public hearing on the classification guidelines was held in July 1996. In each case the OFLC then provided written advice in response to requests for information from the Committee, including 48 questions on notice.
The Committee's views were taken into account in the revisions made to consecutive drafts of the guidelines which were prepared during the review.

I note that the Committee's claim that the review process was conducted with undue secrecy appears to be based on the SCAG convention of not publicly releasing or discussing matters which are under consideration or which are listed for discussion by Censorship Ministers.

The Committee has expressed its dissatisfaction with the review process, suggesting that the OFLC has not addressed its prior recommendation regarding the review of the `R' guidelines in any meaningful sense. However, the Committee was accorded ample opportunity to express its views on the matter, as were all Australian Parliamentarians and members of the public. The review process commenced in October 1995 and was completed in July 1996. The Committee issued a report on the subject after the event in September 1996.

I note from the Hansard that despite the concerns which the Committee has expressed regarding the `R' classification, the Committee considered and commented upon the revised guidelines for each classification category during its hearings on the review of the guidelines.
The Government strongly supports open public consultation and the involvement of experts in the foreshadowed review of guidelines for the classification of publications and computer games.
I am arranging for the Government's response to the Report to be tabled in the Parliament at the earliest opportunity.
Yours sincerely,
(signed)
DARYL WILLIAMS

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to make some remarks on the ministerial response to the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies. Today, the select committee is still in existence, but it has changed its form and gone on to bigger and probably better things. In essence, it is keeping a watching brief on what is being broadcast. Somehow or other we are not able to get away from what is being broadcast. Many members will remember that the other week we had some hearings in this building into Sex/Life and one or two other programs. We are rapidly going more into the whole technological realm. In particular, we are looking at a number of the problems associated with the Internet, e-commerce and other very important developments.

This response from the minister is fairly late in coming; in fact, it picks up recommendations which were made by the previous committee at the end of 1994, early 1995 and in the course of the last quarter of 1996. I note the Attorney-General's response on these matters stemmed from a letter sent by the committee, of which I am the deputy chair, in May this year to speed up a response and find out exactly what was happening.

What the Attorney-General said in his response is rather interesting. He has virtually said they are going to hasten very cautiously; they are going to move very slowly. He agrees that the matter is very important and that there are a number of recommendations which need to be picked up and addressed. The response talks about ministerial council meetings that have taken place over the last three years in an attempt to get some resolutions—in particular, the broadcast of explicitly violent and sexual material.

I am not disagreeing with the Attorney-General's response. I think it is sensible to deal with it as an all-jurisdiction response. I would suggest, however, that anyone who thinks that in the last couple of years all of these measures have had any success is probably not watching a lot of prime time television, which is something I enjoy doing when I am in Canberra. I would suggest the Sunday night movies have become considerably more violent in the last three years.

talk.start.para: —What about the soccer?

—I am not a soccer fan. I am the only one around the place who is not bleary-eyed for that reason. We will be speaking to the Attorney-General again about some of these matters. I note that we are particularly looking at the self-restraint of commercial television broadcasters and radio broadcasters at this stage. There is a difference between the two of them. Certainly in respect of television, there have been a lot of complaints raised by me and other senators about some of the programs that appear on commercial networks. In general, I have some concerns about the timing of some of these programs. I do not have any great problems with them being on television; I have a problem with the time slots. I made that pretty clear at the committee meeting the other week.

speech.para: As to radio broadcasting, there is no doubt that the material being broadcast on a number of radio shows should be available at the local sex shop. If people wish to buy that sort of stuff and they are over the age of 18, then that is where they ought to get it—instead of over the airwaves. That is my own conservative view on these things. I have no problem with adults having access to this material. I think it ought to be packaged and sold in places where it is less likely to fall into the hands of those under the age of 18. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I present the following government response to a committee report: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee—Format of portfolio budget statements. Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows —

para.inline: Government Response to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee's Report "The Format of Portfolio Budget Statements", tabled 30 October 1997.

speech.para: The Government welcomes the report of the Committee into the format of the Portfolio Budget Statements (PBS). The report identifies strengths and weaknesses in the existing PBS document, and provides valuable observations and suggestions for the PBS following the Government's foreshadowed implementation of an accrual budgeting and management framework.

The Committee acknowledges some unique factors which contributed to the generally unfavourable reception for the PBS during the 1996/97 estimates round. The current reference is a result of this generally unfavourable reaction to the documentation.

The Government is pleased to note that the Committee found that there were no major problems with the format of the documents, and that it was supportive of recent and proposed innovations for the current program and outlays based PBS, partic ularly:
. that the reporting format should not be mandated at the micro level for agencies with widely disparate levels of appropriation and numbers of budget measures, and
. changes to the reporting of cross portfolio budget measures.
Purpose of the PBS
The Government agrees with the Committee's view that the purpose of the PBS is to explain the Appropriation Bills to the Parliament, and particularly to the Senate Legislation Committees.

The Government notes the Committee's observation that "the PBS and the process for which they are intended [consideration of estimates by Senate Legislation Committees] are basically mismatched and neither .contributes particularly well to the ostensible purpose of assisting in the passage of the Appropriation Bills", and that "a major stumbling block in the path of program budgeting has always been the cumbersome linkage of the Appropriation Bills to the program framework".

The Government expects that the process of considering estimates, and the linkages between the Appropriation Bills and the PBS documentation, will be greatly improved as a consequence of examining elements of an accrual based budgeting framework and associated documentation.
Response to the recommendations of the report
The report contains three recommendations, but makes a number of other suggestions, observations and comments. Some of these have already been referred to above.
Of the three recommendations, one is directed to the Senate, and the remainder to the Department of Finance and Administration.

The Committee recommended that "all [Senate] legislation committees" be required to comment on the format and content of the PBS". While this is clearly a matter for the Senate to decide, the Government supports such a recommendation. Considered comment on the format and content of the PBS will not only clarify where the format of documentation can be improved, but also each Committee's and portfolio's expectations of the role of the PBS in the consideration of estimates.

The Committee recommended " the Department of Finance [and Administration] circulate its proposed format for the PBS under accrual budgeting, when it is available, to the Committee for comment so that the Committee, and through it the Senate, can have input to the final form of the documentation". The Committee further recommended that "the Department of Finance [and Administration] circulate to the Committee the comments of departments and agencies on the proposed format for the PBS, so that the Committee can be aware of the attitude of those departments and agencies directly".

The Committee noted the substantial number of important issues that need to be resolved if accrual budgeting is to succeed. The Government appreciates the Committee's feedback and the Department of Finance and Administration has noted the points raised. The process of examining aspects of an accrual budgeting framework involves wide ranging consultation and the development of a training curriculum that will be available to all agencies and other stakeholders.

The Department of Finance and Administration proposes to keep the Committee informed on developments in the accrual budgeting project, particularly on areas associated with appropriations and the PBS.

The Department of Finance and Administration is currently developing a draft proposal for the revised PBS. The Department will be consulting widely regarding the contents and refining the draft as appropriate. The Committee's views would be extremely valuable in this regard. The Department sees consultation with the Committee as a high priority and expects to seek input from the Committee at various stages over this year.

The Government notes the Committee's recommendation that the comments of departments and agencies on the proposed format be provided to the Committee. When the Department of Finance and Administration provides a draft of the documentation to the Committee it will include information on the comments received from departments and agencies on the draft.
Conclusion

The Committee's report on the format of Portfolio Budget Statements is a very useful document in clarifying many of the key principles and preferences regarding the documents. The report is very timely as input to the considerations regarding accrual budgeting and will provide valuable guidance in redesigning reporting and accountability arrangements.
The Government sees the Committee as an important stakeholder in considering changes to reporting and accountability and any further input from the Committee is welcomed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to take note of the government's response to the report of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee entitled Format of the portfolio budget state ments . I will only be some four or five minutes and just put on the record the background to this government response. The report of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee arises out of the 1996-97 budget process. Subsequent to that, there was an inquiry conducted by the department arising out of the significant number of complaints as to the inadequacy of the PBSs in that budget estimates process.

The key recommendations that arose from the committee are fairly self-evident—that is, that portfolio budget statements be relatively concise, adhere broadly to a recommended but not standardised format, and refer to ancillary information that is of interest to senators and members of the public but not necessarily repeat it. The committee had three key recommendations, firstly, that the Department of Finance and Administration circulate a proposed format, secondly, that the DOFA circulate the comment of relevant departments and agencies on that format and, thirdly, that all legislation committees, when they give their summary of estimates, comment on the format and adequacy of the portfolio budget statements. I do not have any problem with those recommendations and hope that they are adopted in due course.

I do note in passing that the recommendation of the committee that the PBSs have a reference to ancillary information but not repeat it has been something that has been honoured in the breach, if you like, by the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business. Where there had been significant questioning on particular issues in the Office of Employment Advocate at last year's estimates by Senator Collins and Senator Mackay, and the relevant officials were uncomfortable, or the minister or the government—or both—was uncomfortable with the thread of that questioning, they took the opportunity in this year's PBSs to simply refer us to page whatever or a footnote in the annual report instead of having the same information.

So, instead of that department, or the officials responsible for putting together the PBSs, honouring the intent of the recommendations of the Finance and Public Administra tion Committee and, indeed, the government's response as tabled today, the officials of that department took the opportunity to, at best—if one were being charitable—make it difficult for senators to pursue a particular line of questioning. I formally put that on the record and hope that the department can bring itself to adhere to the necessary processes where individual senators can ask questions that are pertinent to their area of interest.

Two issues arise out of the government recommendations—firstly, accrual budgeting and, secondly, the workload of the Economics Legislation Committee. Firstly, with respect to accrual budgeting, the government, through all departments and agencies, is part way through the implementation of accrual budgeting in the Commonwealth. It is some two or three years before it will be finalised.

Accrual budgeting is a different process from cash budgeting. Cash budgeting is mainly balancing ins and outs, much like the normal chequebook that most people have. As long as the amount that comes in balances what is going out, you do not have a problem. Accrual budgeting is different. It enables departments and accountants to value capital and operational items, outlays of expenditures, over time. Hence, much more information is displayed and much more information can be analysed in terms of the documents, giving greater information to interested readers about the nature of programs, subprograms, outlays, departments and activities of government. It is something that has been part and parcel of corporate life in public companies for many years. You know you have major problems if a company does not have accrual budgeting because you cannot get any accurate information as to the financial state of that company.

With the introduction of accrual budgeting across the Commonwealth, firstly, it is going to give rise to much more information being available and will necessarily lead to an increased volume of questions by individual senators and a different type of question because there is more information on display and, hence, open to examination. That means that estimates will probably be somewhat longer in the future, which is not necessarily a bad thing, but it does suggest the need for staff of senators to be trained adequately in an understanding of accrual budgeting.

It is my knowledge that a lot of staff of senators do not have a proper understanding of financial statements and the intricacies of accrual budgeting. When that is part and parcel of the process of all departments and agencies, it might be appropriate for the relevant employer, at law, to put on a seminar, probably going over 1½ or two days, to explain the process of accrual budgeting, what it means, what its historical roots are and the sort of information that is displayed. In that way, electoral staff of individual senators can engage in serious preparation for the process. I just put that on the record.

The second issue that arises out of the estimates process is the exceptional workload that is carried by the Economics Legislation Committee. It has a range of significant departments—Treasury, Workplace Relations and Small Business, the Sports Commission and others—attached to its responsibilities. Time is always of the essence. Because of that and the nature of the important issues that are covered by those relevant departments, individual senators are not able to examine in sufficient detail the operations of those relevant departments. I know this government is committed to open and transparent government because it has told us so repeatedly. It is possibly time to review the workload of that particular committee.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak on the same matter. I have had quite a deal of interest in the PBSs since I first arrived here, so much so that I think it can be said that, at least in the Defence estimates, the PBS has been changed to fit in with comments I have made on previous occasions at those estimates, and I am very grateful for that.

speech.para: I note in the government's response tonight a number of issues which still concern me and I do not know if they are being addressed properly. Whilst the response refers to the evidence that came out of the 1996-97 years, I do not know if we are really tracking through what is happening with the PBSs. A classic example is in the area of Veterans' Affairs. The Department of Veterans' Affairs set about putting their PBS in a more user-friendly format. Unfortunately, when it came to estimates this year, we found that the PBS as presented by the Department of Veterans' Affairs was not in a user-friendly style at all, so much so that Senator West and I spent quite a deal of time during those estimates trying to unravel the new style that had been presented to us, with the admission coming in the end from Dr Johnston that:
We provided you with more information than last time, but it is not quite as helpful as it could be in some respects.

My concern is not just with this, but I found it also with the Defence PBS. The information they provided did not allow one to follow the trail in terms of the shift in personnel brought about by the defence efficiency review or the defence reform program. It did not allow one to follow the trail in terms of dollar savings.

I must admit that I was very pleased with the response I received from officials of the Department of Defence. They went away and in the space of 24 hours redid the figures, and that enabled one to follow that trail quite clearly from one year to the next. I do not think part of this exercise that has been going on—and I have not noted it anywhere in the government response—is the ability to road-test what the various departments are doing. Whilst they are not constrained to a particular format, one nonetheless must see that, if these things are being revised, they must be in a user-friendly style so that the people who are going to use them in the estimates process can, in some ways, make the estimates process easier by not having to unravel the language in which some of these PBSs are couched.

In particular, I have a concern about the move to accrual accounting. Again, what we must be able to see is the trail from the current cash accounting system to the new accrual accounting system. I note in the government response that they refer to the fact that the Department of Finance and Administration is currently developing a draft proposal for the revised PBS. One would assume that this is according to the report based on the change to accrual accounting. We are going to be in a hopeless mess if this has not in some way been road-tested before it finally gets to the estimates process. I do not know how that would be achieved, but one would think that, in light of the government response and in light of the importance of the estimates process, the government does consider additionally not only that there be a draft proposal for a revised PBS under the accrual accounting system but that this be given some form of road-testing.

I think it is essential that, if the estimates process is to have relevance to us, to the parliament and to the community at large, it must be in a user-friendly style which enables us to follow the progress from one year to the next. That has not been available to date. I have found difficulties on a number of occasions following the PBS from one year to the next. If this is the time to do something about it, then it is appropriate that the government take these comments on board and ensure that we have a user-friendly system which enables us to follow the flow from one year to the next.

This links in directly with the annual reports, and that is another problem which must be overcome. Whilst the annual reports will report a cash based accounting system, they will also have to deal with the transition from cash to accrual. One would hope that this is taken care of in the government response.

I welcome the fact that progress has been made in the revision of the PBS documents that we are challenged to read. But as I said, the main thing that I would hope for in the longer term is that we do get a document which can be widely used. There is a need in some instances for the PBS to be related to the external references that occur in a PBS. The reason I say that is that the PBS for Defence related to a document entitled Future directions for the management of Australia's Defence: Report on the defence efficiency review, and that did provide the basis of many of the decisions and many of the questions that were raised under the 1997-98 PBS and the 1998-99 PBS. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I present the following government response to a committee report: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee—Report on annual reports tabled January 1995—June 1995. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

para.inline: Government Final Response to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee's "Report on Annual Reports Tabled January 1995-June 1995".

speech.para: 1. The Committee recommends that an unclassified annual report by the Office of National Assessments be presented to Parliament.

After careful consideration, the Government has decided not to proceed with an unclassified annual report by the Office of National Assessments. There are already extensive accountability arrangements in place, and there would be difficulty in producing a report that provided meaningful information.

para.inline: 2. The Committee recommends that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, in conjunction with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, develop appropriate guidelines to govern reporting to Parliament by Commonwealth/State bodies with a high level of ex-officio membership, including in this category those bodies which have New Zealand as a member.

speech.para: As the Committee notes, the requirements for reporting on non-statutory bodies (drawn up in 1987) do not apply to Commonwealth-State consultative bodies with high level ex-officio membership only. These are councils or committees, of ministers or senior officials, which provide a forum for discussion and agreement but do not exercise the decision-making responsibilities of the governments represented on them; and their members' activities are only one aspect of the duties of offices they hold subject to more general accountability arrangements. Departments providing secre tariat support for consultative councils are subject to the departmental annual reporting requirements.

Commonwealth governments have been involved through the Council of Australian Governments (COAG), in putting in place protocols and other guidelines regarding the operation of Ministerial Councils and related officials' committees. COAG has agreed that a compendium of ministerial councils should be published and updated, showing in respect of each council its scope and objectives, its composition, chairing arrangements, frequency of meetings, associated meetings of officials, secretariat arrangements, and contact points. The compendium shows any involvement of New Zealand or other regional ministers or officials.

The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet's Commonwealth-State Relations Secretariat published the compendium in 1992 and 1994, and it is intended to update it regularly. When the Department next writes to other departments about their own reporting requirements, it will remind them of the Parliament's interest in any participation in and support they provide for Commonwealth-State consultative councils.

para.inline: 3. The Committee recommends that the Australia New Zealand Land Information Council annual report be presented to Parliament.

speech.para: The Australia New Zealand Land Information Council has agreed to publish a National Report covering the period 1994-97 and annual reports subsequently, which will be submitted to the Committee.

para.inline: 4. The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Spatial Data Committee annual report be presented to Parliament.

speech.para: The Commonwealth Spatial Data Committee has provided the Senate Committee with copies of its 1995-96 and 1996-97 annual reports and intends to continue this practice.

para.inline: 5. The Committee recommends that the Construction Industry Ministers' Conference report to Parliament, either separately, or within the Department of Administrative Services annual report.

speech.para: The Australian Procurement and Construction Ministers Council (APCC) was formed in October 1996 and performs the role previously provided by the Construction Industry Ministers Conference. The APCC, including the secretariat function, is jointly funded by Federal, State and Territory governments. A report on the Department of Finance and Administration's involvement with the APCC will be included in future annual reports of the Department.

para.inline: 6. The Committee recommends that the Australian Liaison Committee on Remote Sensing by Satellite report to Parliament, either separately, or within the Department of Administrative Services annual report.

speech.para: The Australian Liaison Committee on Remote Sensing by Satellite was disbanded in 1993.

para.inline: 7. The Committee recommends that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet consult with the Land Councils and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, concerning both the appropriate means for reporting by Aboriginal Land Trusts to Parliament, and the nature of the information to be supplied.

speech.para: Land Trusts are established primarily to hold title to land, and to deal with estates and interests relating to that land at the direction of the respective Land Councils. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs will contact Land Councils to settle arrangements regarding coverage of such dealings in the annual reports of Land Councils, which are tabled in the Parliament.

para.inline: 8. The Committee recommends that the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council financial statements be presented annually to Parliament.

speech.para: The recently passed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997 requires Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council to table annual reports in the Parliament commencing with the financial year ending June 1998.

para.inline: 9. The Committee recommends that, while the Advisory Council for Inter-government relations remains a statutory authority (though inactive), a note to this effect be placed, either in the annual report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, or in the information available on request.

speech.para: A note about the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations was included in the information made available on request in association with the Department's annual reports for 1994-95 and 1995-96. The practice of including such a note will continue as long as it is appropriate.

para.inline: 10. The Committee recommends that departmental annual reports, or material available on request, include information on any inactive statutory authority or non-statutory body, to allow monitoring of compliance with reporting requirements.

speech.para: Departments are required to make available on request information about portfolio legislation and statutory authorities. Inactive statutory authorities should be shown as such in this information. The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet will advise departments accordingly when it writes to them next about reporting requirements. It will also remind departments to include in information available on request notes on any non-statutory bodies which have become inactive without ceasing to exist.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I present the government response to a committee report: Employment, Education and Training References Committee—Childhood matters: report on the inquiry into early childhood education. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Introduction

In July 1996, the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee released its report `Childhood Matters' on their inquiry into early childhood education. The terms of reference for the inquiry were broad ranging, concentrating on the experience of Australian children up to age seven and included:
The examination of recent research dealing with:
- early childhood factors which impact upon capacity to learn during formal school education;
- the impact of early childhood education on learning success in later years; and
- the role of parents as early childhood educators, particularly with respect to literacy and cognitive skills generally.

Analysis, and cost assessment of, remedial and other interventions required in the primary and middle school years to enable students to achieve the necessary learning competencies for successful completion of secondary education to Year 12, and to provide a basis for independent, lifelong learning.

Examination of recent notable early childhood education initiatives in Australia and OECD countries and report on any implications for, or desirable changes to, Commonwealth policies and priorities in education and child support.

Assessment of the existing relationships and policy interface between the early childhood services sectors and the schools sector in Australia and report on their effectiveness in achieving the successful transition of children into formal schooling.

The report makes 24 recommendations across child care, preschool and the early years of schooling. Broadly, the Committee advocates a view of early childhood services which embraces both education and care, drawing child care and preschool together. Recommendations have implications for Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments.
Many of the issues covered by the Committee of relevance to the Commonwealth have been examined, independent of the Senate inquiry, through a range of Commonwealth Government initiated processes.

The Government response to `Childhood Matters' has been prepared in a climate of significant change for both of the major portfolio areas responding to the report; the Department of Health and Family Services and the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA).

In broad terms the Commonwealth Government's direction for children's services is one which will provide equity and fairness in the distribution of quality child care to Australian families. The Government's strategies regarding the provision of child care are also designed to ensure that the child care sector remains affordable and sustainable for both families and governments into the future.

Although the Commonwealth Government had historical links in the provision of preschool education, changes to Federal Government policies introduced under successive Governments since the 1970s have led to the current situation where the responsibility for development of the preschool system and the provision of preschool services has been fully transferred to State and Territory Governments. From 1985, the Commonwealth's Children's Services Program has been directed to the development of child care services, primarily to support female participation in the paid workforce. Preschool education is no longer a Commonwealth responsibility, and, except under the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy, DEETYA policy responsibilities in the early childhood education area are only in relation to children attending school and include some preschool programs delivered on school premises in Queensland and Western Australia.

The Commonwealth Government's child care reform process commenced in the 1996-97 Budget and provides a strong foundation for the future development of the Program. The Government has allocated an estimated $4.7 billion on child care over the next four years, with expenditure expected to grow from $1 billion in 1997-98 to $1.3 billion in 2001-2002. Reforms target more equitable assistance to families irrespective of the service used, offer fair and reasonable access to funded care and appropriate distribution of new services to meet family needs.
The reforms are the result of extensive family research and consultations with parents and industry.

In terms of education, the Commonwealth Government takes a broad view of the elements necessary to achieve high quality outcomes from the Australian education system. The Government makes a direct link between the availability of high quality education, including early childhood education, and an individual's employment potential in later life. In developing and implementing education policy the Government remains focused on the links between high quality education and the economic development and social well being of Australians generally.

The Commonwealth Government accepts a role of leadership in school education in recognition of the vital significance high quality school education is to the future of Australia. As part of its contribution to the national effort for Australian schooling the Commonwealth provides supplementary funding to States/Territories and to non-government school authorities to assist in the achievement of specific objectives agreed upon by the Commonwealth and the States/Territories.
It is within this context that the Government provides the following responses to the recommendations presented in the Senate Committee's report `Childhood Matters'.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government through the Minister for Health and Family Services establish a National Centre for Research in Early Childhood Development, Education and Care, possibly based on an existing research facility. The National Centre will:

conduct longitudinal and other studies into the cognitive, emotional and social development of children from birth, including studies of children whose development is at risk because of economic, social or disability factors; and
contribute to the development of theory on child development and on early childhood practice from the perspective of Australian research findings.

speech.para: The Commonwealth Government supports the conduct of longitudinal and other relevant studies into early childhood education and care particularly with a focus on the Australian experience.

There is value in comprehensive and nationally relevant research into early childhood because early childhood experiences are known to have a far reaching impact on a child's emotional, social, physical and intellectual development. A longitudinal, Australian focused, approach to research would provide valuable insights into the effectiveness and appropriateness of our early childhood services. The Government already supports quality research projects and draws on the findings of such research in the development of Government policy.

Separate portfolio areas covering early childhood, Health and Family Services and Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, currently fund and oversee a wide range of research projects. The Australian Institute of Family Studies currently undertakes longitudinal research and data collection on a range of family and community welfare issues, including childhood development, which promote a greater understanding of the needs and profiles of families targeted by all levels of Government.

In 1996, DEETYA directly funded early childhood education research through grants for early childhood literacy research. The Australian Council for Education Research and Schools of Early Childhood Education within higher education institutions also undertake research into early childhood issues.

Given the diverse nature of existing research arrangements, the Commonwealth will continue to consider opportunities to maximise access to relevant research and data regarding the provision of services for children and to utilise this information in the context of longer term policy directions.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that, in determining approvals for the establishment of child care facilities, planning authorities take into account the viability of proposals brought before them in the light of existing patterns of provision in the area.

speech.para: This recommendation has been addressed by the Commonwealth Government's 1997-98 Budget measures, including the National Planning System, National Information Strategy and supply limits. These measures will provide for more equitable access to subsidised child care for families and better distribution of new child care services which will support sustainable growth in the sector. As a result of participation in these processes, Local Government will have improved access to relevant information on which to assess the viability of proposals for expansion of service delivery.

The Commonwealth Government's vision for delivering a sustainable child care system that provides accessible, affordable and high quality child care will be complemented by the National Information Strategy, a component of which aims to better inform investor decisions.

The National Planning System and the decision to slow the rate of growth of centre based long day care to 7,000 new child care places for the calendar years 1998 and 1999 will ensure that new places approved for Childcare Assistance establish in identified priority areas.

para.inline: The Committee recommends that the governments of the Commonwealth, States and Territories devise consistent nomenclature and descriptors for the years of early childhood and of compulsory schooling. This will entail:
common nomenclature for the primary school years and the `pre-primary school' years; and;
a common starting age for, and a common date of eligibility for entry to, compulsory schooling, and similarly for the year before compulsory schooling (the so-called `preschool' year).

The Committee suggests that, in all States and Territories, the first year of compulsory schooling should be designated `Year 1'; the year immediately before `Year 1' should be designated `Preschool'.

speech.para: The Commonwealth Government recognises the merit of this recommendation and acknowledges the confusion experienced by families by the current inconsistencies in nomenclature and school starting ages.

The report has been referred to State and Territory Government Ministers with responsibility for children's services and education for their consideration. Examination of issues concerning national consistency across child care, preschool and primary schooling is important if the anomalies which currently exist within these services and across States and Territories are to be redressed. There is also a need to ensure fair and equal access to quality services across Australia and to facilitate portability of a child's educational status between the States and Territories.

While State and Territory governments have the major responsibility for school education, including the standardisation of grade entry points, the Commonwealth also has an interest in common entry points for all students in all sectors of schooling.
