talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of the campaign by Bronwyn Davis of Hobart's Prego Restaurant reported in the Mercury, 11 May 1998, against the proposed tips taxes.

(2) Is the Government considering such taxes or has the Australian Taxation Office entertained the option; if so: (a) has the Government dismissed the option; (b) what representations have been made to or by the Minister alluding to tips taxes during this period of office; (c) what impact would such taxes have on employment; and (d) is there a means of ensuring such a tax is tailored to each individual's income derived from tips.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, I have been advised about an article in the Mercury of 11 May 1998, which refers to a campaign by Miss Davis against a supposed tips tax.

(2) The Mercury article suggests that the Government is proposing to introduce a tax on tips received by workers in the hospitality industry as part of its tax reform proposals. The Government will announce its tax reform proposals at the appropriate time. But in any event, the article ignores the fact that tips are already subject to income tax under existing tax arrangements. Tips received by waiters, hospitality workers, taxi drivers and the like are ordinary income, which is taxable in the same way as other income. This has been the tax position in Australia since at least 1936.

subdebateinfo.title: Next Round of the Australia-China Human Rights Dialogue
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1197)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to the next round of the proposed bilateral dialogue between the Governments of China and Australia:
(1) (a) What is the date of the talks; (b) where will the talks be held; (c) who will be party to the talks; and (d) what are the issues to be discussed.
(2) Will the Australian Government raise with the Chinese Government the issue of human rights, with particular references to the situation in Tibet and Eastern Turkestan.
(3) Will the Minister be seeking input and/or advice be sought from non-Government organisations (NGOs) in the development of the Government's briefing material.
(4) Will any NGOs be present at the talks, either as observers or participants; if so, who will they be; if not, why not.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The talks are expected to be held in August; (b) the talks will be held in Canberra, followed by associated discussions with various institutions in one or two other cities, the details of which have yet to be finalised; (c) the composition of the respective delegations is also still to be finalised; (d) although the agenda is yet to be finalised, we anticipate that the talks will provide an opportunity to follow up on a range of issues raised last year in Beijing, including the human rights situation in Tibet and that affecting other ethnic and religious minorities within China, treatment of dissidents, and China's progress in accession to the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR) and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR).
(2) As indicated above, the situation of human rights in China will be raised, including the situation of ethnic and religious minorities.

(3) and (4) These are officials-level talks, which form part of a comprehensive pattern of bilateral discussions with China on a range of issues, including disarmament and regional security, international and regional political issues, economic issues, aid, cultural and consular issues. We regularly consult with the Australian NGO community on a wide range of human rights issues, and will continue to do so in the lead-up to the Australia-China human rights dialogue as part of our efforts to ensure that Australian community concerns are reflected in the dialogue discussions. As was the case last year, we will provide a full post-dialogue briefing at the next round of DFAT-NGO human rights consultations.
